texts.en: Mrs. Cheam M., 30, is married with 3 children, staying at home cooking food and looking after her children. After the housework, Mrs. M. uses her time to purchase bananas in her community and resells them to the market, earning around $3 a day of profit. Her husband, Mr. Me Moeun, 37, is also a banana seller. He purchases bananas from his community and resells them to the market, making around $2.50 a day of profit. This couple hopes to use this loan to purchase bananas in large amounts to meet their growing customer demands.

loans.use: This couple hopes to use this loan to purchase bananas in large amounts to meet their growing customer demands.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en:
Sandra is in her late thirties, and she and her husband have five children, three of them girls. They all attend school. Sandra produces homemaD. juices. Sandra’s juices are maD. from a wiD. variety of natural fruits such as pineapple, orange, melon, and strawberry. She also prepares some succulent mixes of oats with milk.

Sandra hopes that in the future she can have her own locale where she can run the business. She plans on using her loan to expand her business. She will offer a wider variety of juices and add sandwiches to her inventory.

loans.use: To expand her small business and offer sandwiches to her clientele

loans.name: Kamwokya C Group

texts.en:
Catherine N. is a 37-year-old mother of seven children in Kamuli, Uganda. She earns a living selling charcoal, making about $10,000 Ugandan shillings (the equivalent of $9 U.S. dollars) each week. In order to pay for her children's mandatory school fees, Catherine hopes to expand her business.

Catherine has applied for a loan of $1,200 U.S. dollars along with four other women. Ayoa has taken out a loan before and paid it back on time, so she is confident that she will be able to repay this one as well. In this type of group loan, the money is divided among each woman to invest in her own business. They guarantee each other's loans, so that if one woman can't repay it, the others will cover her share. Eva M. wants to grow her retail shop; Ruth K. hopes to grow her fish market; Norah N. plans on buying more fruit for her produce stand; and Miranda B. wants to build up her charcoal-selling business.

loans.use: To add in charcoal business and make more profits

loans.name: Kamwokya C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Catherine N.. She is currently in the business of charcoal selling and is requesting a loan to boost business. Catherine is 37 years old and is married. She has 7 children ranging from age 5 to 20. Each week, Catherine makes approximately UGX 10000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able pay school fees for the children. Harriet has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 in order to increase stock and the loan was paid back on time.

Harriet is joined in her small group by Eva M., Ruth K. , Norah N. and Miranda B.. Eva M. has a retail shop and wants to add in stock. Ruth K. sells fish and wants to boost business with the loan. Norah N. operates a fruit selling business and intends to increase stock. Miranda B. sells charcoal and wants to expand business

loans.use: To add in charcoal business and make more profits

loans.name: Ana Mercedes

texts.en:
Ana Mercedes is a many-sided businesswoman who is looking for the best market opportunities to do business. She is a teacher in a primary school in the Café community of Santo Domingo. She also sells silver jewelry to women and other teachers in the school and the community.

Ana Mercedes says that she wants to start selling calling cards too, because these products are always in high demand, and she thinks she could earn a lot of money selling them.

Ana is requesting a loan to invest in the purchase of more jewelry in order to increase her income. The entrepreneur wants to improve her family’s living conditions and keep supporting her three children's studies.

loans.use: Purchase of silver jewelry for her business inventory

loans.name: Ndidi

texts.en: H. Ndidi has been in the business of selling building materials since 2001.   He is 42 years old, married with 4 children, and lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.  He needs the loan of $1025 to buy more building materials.

loans.use: To buy more building materials for sale

loans.name: Naila

texts.en:
Naila (her daughter is pictured) has been in business for two years, making and selling bread. Her daughter works with her in the business.

The family lives in the Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan. Naila was born in 1967 and has two children. She is requesting a loan of $725 to purchase flour and other products for use in the baking and selling of her bread.

loans.use: To purchase flour and other products for baking bread

loans.name: Kamwokya D Group

texts.en:
Ayoa N. is a 35-year-old mother of four children in Kamuli, Uganda. She runs a small pharmacy, while her husband is a teacher. Ayoa hopes to expand her business; with the extra profits, she plans on meeting basic needs, such as home repairs, mandatory school fees for her children, and clothing.

Ayoa has applied for a loan of $1,300 U.S. dollars along with four other women. Ayoa has taken out a loan before and paid it back on time, so she is confident that she will be able to repay this one as well. In this type of group loan, the money is divided among each woman to invest in her own business. They guarantee each other's loans, so that if one woman can't repay it, the others will cover her share. Fidah M. has a business in charcoal selling and wants to expand it, while Lydia A. hopes to buy a fridge for her bar. Asiya N. grows matooke, or green bananas (a popular food stape in Uganda), and wants to buy more supplies to plant more crops. Lastly, Ayoa N. wishes to buy more stock for her food-selling shop.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine for a local pharmacy

loans.name: Juana Milaria

texts.en:
Juana Milaria is a forty-three-year-old single mother who is making great efforts to support her five children’s studies and face their household issues. She has been running a small grocery store for a little more than one year in El Cacique community of Yamasá. Juana explains that in the beginning she operated the business in her house as she didn’t have enough money to rent a locale for the store.

After many months of hard work and persistence, Juana’s grocery store is starting to be very profitable. Currently Juana even plans on moving the business to a small locale she will rent before long to continue her business. The entrepreneur will use her loan to invest in the rental of the locale. She will also purchase many products to restock the grocery store.

loans.use: To invest in the rental of a small locale for her business

loans.name: Tweyimbe A Group

texts.en:
Suzan N. is a 31-year-old mother of four young children living Kamuli, Uganda. She makes a living by raising poultry, while her husband runs a welding business. Each week, Suzan earns $15,000 Ugandan shillings, or $9 U.S. dollars, each week. She hope to expand her business; with the extra profits, she plans on meeting basic needs, such as home repairs, school fees for her children, and clothing.

Suzan has applied for a loan of $1,125 U.S. dollars along with three other women. Suzan has taken out a loan before and paid it back on time, so she is confident that she will be able to repay this one as well. In this type of group loan, the money is divided among each woman to invest in her own business. They guarantee each other's loans, so that if one woman can't repay it, the others will cover her share. Rose M. wishes to buy a fridge for her retail store, while Jennifer J. wants to expand her pig-rearing business. Jesca N. hopes to buy staples to expand her small retail shop.

loans.use: To buy materials to expand a poultry business

loans.name: Pavlina

texts.en: Pavlina I. lives in the village of Mighailovo near Vratza. She is married and has two kids. Together with her husband, she breeds two cows and now wants to buy one more. That’s why she has applied for this loan.

loans.use: To buy one more cow

loans.name: Louisa

texts.en: Louisa N. is a married woman with 7 children. She is 43 years old and lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells soft drinks and has been in business since 2000. She needs the loan of $875 to buy more crates of drinks for sale. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more soft drinks for sale

loans.name: Emil

texts.en: Emil K. has had a farming business for three years. He lives with his family in the village of Manastirishte neat Vratza. His wife is unemployed. Emil breeds 5 cows and needs to buy fodder for them.

loans.use: To buy fodder for his cows

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en: Bernadette E., 48, lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria, and is married with 3 children.  She has been in the business of selling clothes since 1993.  . She needs the loan amount of $875 to buy more clothes, shoes and bags for sale

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Aliosha

texts.en: Aliosha V. is divorced, but he takes care of his three kids. Now he lives with another woman and is expecting a fourth child. Aliosha breeds 3 cows in his own cowshed in the village of Barzina near Vratza and now wants to buy one more.

loans.use: To buy one more cow

loans.name: Seyidaga

texts.en: Seyidaga was born in 1983, is single and lives in the town of Khachmaz. He has owned his business for three years. Mr. A. is requesting a loan of $725 to purchase additional food products for his grocery store..

loans.use: To purchase inventory for a grocery store

loans.name: Tweyimbe B Group

texts.en:
Monic N. is a 41-year-old mother of six children who range in age from 6 to 25. She makes a living by running a poultry business in Kamuli, Uganda, and wishes to buy more merchandise to expand her store. Currently, she earns $25,0000 Ugandan shillings, or $12 U.S. dollars, each week; with the extra profits, she plans on covering basic needs like shelter.

Monic has applied for a loan of $1,300 U.S. dollars along with three other women. In this type of group loan, the money is divided among each woman to invest in her own business. They guarantee each other's loans, so that if one woman can't repay it, the others will cover her share. Veronica M. wishes to grow her retail store, while Jackie N. hopes to expand her sweet potato company. With her portion, Olivia N. wants to buy a poultry feeder for her poultry business. Monic has taken out a loan before and paid it back on time, so she is confident that she will be able to repay this one as well.

loans.use: To buy chicks to grow her poultry business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Bogdana

texts.en: Bogdana A. is 22 years old, but already has four kids. She lives with her boyfriend who is a constructor and works in the capital city of Sofia. Bogdana breeds 7 goats on a farm in her native village. The loan she is applying for will be spent on buying fodder.

loans.use: To buy fodder

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en: Vilma T. lives in the village of Rogozen. She is married and has three kids. Her husband works in the capital city of Sofia. Vilma breeds a cow and now wants to buy another one.

loans.use: To buy one more cow

loans.name: Plamen

texts.en: Plamen R. is an electronic and radio technician. He used to work in a factory, but six years ago he started his farming business. Now he breeds 20 sheep. His wife is unemployed. Plamen has two sons, but they are grown up and take care of themselves. Plamen now applies for this loan, which will be used for buying fodder for the flock.

loans.use: To buy fodder for the flock

loans.name: Aleksi

texts.en: Aleksi A. is 34 years old. He is single and lives with his parents in the village of Barzina, near Vratza. Aleksi works in a ferrous metals factory, but he also breeds three cows and wants to buy one more.

loans.use: To buy one more cow

loans.name: Tweyimbe C Group

texts.en:
Edith B. is a 42-year-old widow and mother of two. She makes a living by running a battery charging business Kamuli, Uganda, and wishes to buy a large battery. Currently, she earns $25,0000 Ugandan shillings, or $15 U.S. dollars, each week. With the extra profits, she plans on covering basic needs, such as home repairs.

Jane has applied for a loan of $1,300 U.S. dollars along with three other women. In this type of group loan, the money is divided among each woman to invest in her own business. They guarantee each other's loans, so that if one woman can't repay it, the others will cover her share. Besi M. wishes to buy a fridge for her retail shop, Justine K. wants to buy cloth for her tailoring store, while Mwajuma A. hopes to grow her poultry business. Edith has taken out a loan before and paid it back on time, so she is confident that she will be able to repay this one as well.

loans.use: To buy a battery to expand a battery charging business

loans.name: Regina

texts.en: Regina I., from Edo State, Nigeria, is married with 4 children. She is 41 years old and has been in the business of selling clothes since 1994.  She needs the loan amount of $875 to buy more clothes for sale.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Ilonka

texts.en: Ilonka H. is married and lives with her husband and their two kids in the village of Mramoren near Vratza. She breeds 10 sheep and needs to buy three more. Daily, she gets about 15 litres of milk that she sells to one of the biggest dairies in the region.

loans.use: To buy three more sheep

loans.name: Elka

texts.en: Elka S. lives with her husband in the village of Barzina. They have three kids. Both Elka and her husband were unemployed. That’s why, three years ago, they started their farming business. Now they own a cowshed and 8 cows. Now they need to supply some fodder for their cows and need financial support.

loans.use: To supply some fodder

loans.name: Bakha

texts.en: Bakha has been in the business of selling clothes for three years. This young man was born in 1985 and is single. He lives in the town of Khachmaz. He is requesting a loan of $725 to buy additional clothing to sell in his business.

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Genoveva

texts.en: Together with her husband, Genoveva M. breeds 15 cows in her own farm around the village of Medkovetz near Vratza. The couple also have land that they lend to other agricultural producers in the region. Now they need to buy two more cows and so they have applied for a loan.

loans.use: To buy 2 more cows

loans.name: Bubulete I A Group

texts.en:
Justine B. is a 32-year-old mother of three young children. She and her husband make a living by running a retail store in Kamuli, Uganda, and wish to buy more merchandise to expand her store. With the extra profits, she hopes to start a new business.

Justine has applied for a loan of $825 U.S. dollars along with two other women. In this type of group loan, the money is divided among each woman to invest in her own business. They guarantee each other's loans, so that if one woman can't repay it, the others will cover her share. Sarah Namulida wants to grow her charcoal selling business, while Betty Nakianda hopes to purchase a fridge for her small brewery. Justine has taken out a loan before and paid it back on time, so she is confident that she will be able to repay this one as well.

loans.use: To buy merchandise to expand her retail shop

loans.name: Stefka

texts.en: Stefka Z. lives in the village of Mighailovo near Vratza. For more than 20 years, she has had a farming business. Now she breeds 8 cows and 15 goats. Her husband works in a construction company and her son is grown up and lives in the city of Vratza. Stefka Z. applies for a loan to supply enough fodder for her farm.

loans.use: To supply enough fodder for her farm

loans.name: Tatiana

texts.en: Tatiana T. is 24 years old. She is alone and lives with her two kids in her parents house in the village of Manastirishte near Vratza. Tatiana is unemployed. For a year, she has bred two cows in the yard of her house and needs to buy fodder to feed them.

loans.use: To buy fodder

loans.name: Aksinia

texts.en: Aksinia D. lives in the village of Resovo near Vratza. She keeps a grocery store the village. Aksinia is married and has two sons. Her husband works as a driver. The grocery store is the only one in the village and has many clients. Now, Aksinia D. needs to enlarge the variety of goods that she offers, so she has applied for this loan.

loans.use: To supply the grocery store

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther O. is 33 years old, married, and in the business of selling baby things. She learned her trade over a period of 4 years. She is from Edo State, Nigeria, and has been in business since 2000. She needs the loan amount of $875 to buy additional baby supplies for sale.

loans.use: To buy more baby things for sale.

loans.name: Radoslav

texts.en: Radoslav D. keeps a café in the village of Mighailovo near Vratza. Radoslav is 39 years old. He is single, and for three years he has worked in Germany. After returning to his native village, he opened his café and now needs some financial help to make some repairs.

loans.use: To make some repairs to the cafe

loans.name: Loveth

texts.en: S. Loaveth is 40 years old, married with 3 children, and comes from Ilaje Area of Lagos State, Nigeria.  She has been in business since 1999, using a manual ceiling machine for the production of  pure water (sachet water).  She needs the loan amount of $775 to increase her production of sachet water for sale

loans.use: To buy a ceiling machine and other material needed for the production of pure water

loans.name: Gulnaz

texts.en: Gulnaz is the mother of two children. She was born in 1958. The Hadjimatov family lives in the town of Khachmaz.. She started this business four years ago as a way of supporting her family. Mrs. H. requests a loan of $775 to buy a larger inventory of clothes for resale.

loans.use: To purchase a larger inventory of clothes for resale

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin A. is 43 years old, married with 5 children, and hails from Iba Area in Lagos State, Nigeria.  She has been in the business of selling drugs, provisions and cosmetics since 1998. She needs a loan of $775 to buy more drugs and cosmetics for sale. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more drugs, provisions and cosmetics

loans.name: Romoke

texts.en: Romoke D. is 37 years old, married, has 2 children and hails from Iba Area in Lagos State.  She has been in the business of selling provisions and foodstuffs since 2000 and needs the loan amount of $450 to buy more supplies for sale.

loans.use: to buy more provisions and foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Vugar

texts.en: Vugar was born in 1979. This single man lives in the town of Khachmaz. He has operated his cattle breeding business for five years. Mr. A. is requesting a loan of $725 to purchase a cow to improve his cattle business.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Tursunoy

texts.ru:
Tursunoy A. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. She is 45 years old, divorced and has 2 children. She has a high school degree, but not professional degree. Mrs. A. has been managing a general goods store for the last four years. Mrs. A. is planning to use the loan to improve her sales by expanding the assortment of goods her store offers for sale. She is hoping to pay back the loan in the next 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Абдухалимова Турсуной жительница города Т урсунзаде. Возраст 45 лет, разведена, имеет 2 детей. Образование среднее, специальности не имеет. Занимается торговлей. Имеет магазин. Планируемый кредит хочет использовать на расширение бизнеса, увеличить товарооборот, путем ввоза нового ассортимента товара. Опыт в бизнесе 4 года. Рассчитывает погасить планируемый кредит в течении 12 месяцев

loans.use: Purchase of goods

loans.name: Justina

texts.en: Justina O. is 48 years old, married with 7 children, and hails from Iba Area in Lagos State.  She has been in the business of selling foodstuffs in her community for 4 years. She needs the loan amount of $700 to buy more food items for sale.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Risikat

texts.en: Risikat T. is 35 years old, married, has 5 children and comes from Iba Area of Lagos State, Nigeria.  She has been in the business of selling foodstuffs since 1997 and needs the loan amount of $700 to buy more foodstuffs for sale. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Avliyokul

texts.ru:
Avliyokul A. lives in the city of Yavan. He is 59 years old, not married and has 7 children. He has a high school degree, but no profession. He has been raising cattle for milk and meat sales for the last 20 years. He mainly purchases calves at Yavan's markets, fattens them and sells them at the same markets for profit. Mr. A. is planning to use the loan to expand his business and increase animal turnover. This loan will not only help Mr. A. support himself and his family, but will also expand agriculture in the region and provide a source of meat, milk and sour milk products to the local residents. Mr. A. is planning to pay back the loan in the next 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Асторнаев Авлиекул житель города Яван.Возраст 59 лет. Неженат , имеет 7 детей.Образование среднее, специальной работы не имеет. Основной вид деятельности животноводство.Опыт в данной сфере 20 лет.Кредит планирует получить для расширения деятельности. То есть хочет увеличить товарооборот.Место ведение бизнеса Рынки города Яван. Приобретает крупно рогатый скот, откармливает и продает на тех же рынках. Данная деятельность является не только источником дохода клиента но и помогает развитию сельскохозяйственного сектора , а также обеспечить население молоком и кисломолочными продуктами. Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Marcelline

texts.fr:
Born in 1977 in Dangbo, located in the southeast of Benin in the Oueme Valley, the second richest valley in Africa, Marcelline H. is married and the mother of two.  She sells fruit retail and envisions selling fruit wholesale.   She is requesting a loan to develop her business and to satisfy a constantly growing customer demand. Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer


Née en 1977 à DANGBO dans la vallée de L’OUEME au sud-est du BENIN, deuxième vallée plus riche de L’AFRIQUE, dame H. Marcelline est mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle vend des fruits  en détail et envisage la vente en gros. Elle sollicite ce crédit pour développer son activité et satisfaire la demande sans cesse croissante de sa clientèle.

loans.use: To buy fruit:  pineapples, oranges, bananas, papayas

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Alidé - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Hikmatullo.

texts.ru:
Hikimatullo Z. is a resident of the city of Vahdat. He is 39 years old, married and has 2 children. He has a professional degree in woodworking. For the last four years Mr. Z. has been selling groceries at a store in Vahdat. He is planning to use the loan to increase the goods turnover in his store by expanding the selection of groceries he is offering. This loan will help support Mr. Z.'s grocery store and allow the locals to buy food in their own city at low prices. Mr. Z. is planning to pay back the loan in the next 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Зарипов Хикматулло житель города Вахдат, возраст 39 лет.женат имеет 2 детей. Образование средне-специальное. По специальности плотник. Занимается торговлей продуктов питания. Имеет торговую точку в городе Вахдат . На запланированный кредит хочет увеличит товарооборот путем расширения ассортимента товара. Опыт в бизнесе 4 года. Этот бизнес дает возможность населению покупать товар в своем городе по доступным ценам Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Expanding selection of goods for sale

loans.name: Dilorom

texts.ru:
Dilorom K. is a resident of Tursun-zoda. She is 28 years old and is married with 3 children. She has a high school degree. Dilorom is planing to use the loan to purchase a milk cow. This loan will allow her to provide cheap milk for her family and sell milk to the locals, thus improving the financial situation of the family. She is planning to pay back the loan in the next 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Курбоналиева Дилором Жительница города Турсунзаде. Возраст 28 лет, замужем имеет 3 детей. Образование среднее. Планируемый кредит хочет использовать на приобретение дойной коровы для того чтобы получать молоко для своей семьи и на продажу, что поможет улучшить финансовое положение семьи.Кредит планирует погасить в течении 10 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of a milk cow

loans.name: Stilian

texts.en: Stilian S. lives in the village of Rasovo near Vratza. He is 37 years old but still lives with his elderly parents and looks after them. For six years, Stilian has had a farming business. He breeds 15 sheep on a farm in his village. There is significant interest in sheep milk in the region, so Stilian wants to enlarge his farm and buy three more sheep.

loans.use: To buy three more sheep

loans.name: Bagulete I B Group

texts.en:
Jane M. is a 30-year-old mother of five young children. She makes a living by running a retail store in Kamuli, Uganda, and wishes to buy more merchandise to expand her store. Currently, she earns 20,0000 Ugandan shillings, or 12 U.S. dollars, each week. With the extra profits, she plans on covering basic needs, such as home repairs, clothes, and mandatory school fees.

Jane has applied for a loan of $825 U.S. dollars along with two other women. In this type of group loan, the money is divided among each woman to invest in her own business. They guarantee each other's loans, so that if one woman can't repay it, the others will cover her share. Ruth B. hopes to grow her grocery store, and Lovisa K. wants to expand her retail shop. Jane has taken out a loan before and paid it back on time, so she is confident that she will be able to repay this one as well.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise to expand a retail store

loans.name: Bagulete Ii A Group

texts.en:
Hadijah N. is a 37-year-old mother of three living in Kamuli, Uganda. She makes a living running a retail shop, earning $20,000 Ugandan shillings—or $12 U.S. dollars—a week. A loan could help her expand her store. Hadijah says she'd use the extra profits to help her family meet basic needs. One of their greatest expenses is paying for her children's school fees.

Hadijah has applied for a loan of $1,150 U.S. dollars along with four other women. In this type of group loan, the money is divided among each woman to invest in her own business. They guarantee each other's loans, so that if one woman can't repay it, the others will cover her share. Berna W. will use her portion to buy more piglets for her pig-rearing business, while Salma N. wants to purchase a fridge for her retail shop. Meanwhile, Rashid N. will start a new business and Jesca Kimbumba hopes to grow her retail shop.

loans.use: To buy more stock to expand a retail shop

loans.name: Tulkunboy

texts.ru:
Tulkunboy M. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. He is 40 years old, married and has 4 children. Mr. M. has finished high school and has no professional degree. For the last 4 years he has been operating a bakery which produces issik-non, Tajik flat bread. Mr. M. is planning to use his loan to purchase flour wholesale for his business. The loan will help him to expand his business and support his family as well as be able to provide the locals with bread. Mr. M. is planning to pay back his loan in the next 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Мадрахимов Тулкунбой житель города Турсунзаде.40 лет, женат , имеет 4 детей Образование среднее , специальности не имеет. Работает частным предпринимателем в сфере производства. Имеет цех по выпеканию лепешек. Общий опыт в данной деятельности 4 года. Кредит планирует использовать на приобретение муки. Этот бизнес помогает клиенту зарабатывать для своей семьи ,а также обеспечить население данным видом продукции по более доступным ценам. Кредит погасить клиент планирует в течении 10 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of flour

loans.name: Bufanala A Group

texts.en:
Annet K. is a 37-year-old mother of two living in Kamuli, Uganda. She makes a living by running a retail shop. Each week, she makes $20,000 Ugandan shillings a week—or about $12 U.S. dollars. With her share of the loan, she wishes to buy more stock to expand her store. She's taken out loan before to kickstart her business, and paid it back in full and on time.

Annet is investing in a loan of $900 U.S. dollars with three other women. In this type of group loan, the funds are distributed among the members, each of whom invests in her own business. They all guarantee each other's loans, so if one member can't repay, the others are responsible. Margret A. wants to grow her business trading produce, while Monica N. wishes to do the same with her grocery store. Lastly, Annet B. also wants to develop her grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to expand a retail shop

loans.name: Malika

texts.ru:
Malika M., 38, lives in Tursun-Zoda, Tajikistan. She is married and has 5 children. Malika is a cattle farmer. She plans to use this loan to purchase young bulls to be raised and then profitably resold in the summer. Malika plans to repay this loan within 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Мадрахимова Малика, проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возрат 38 лет , замужем имеет 5 детей. Образование среднее , специальности не имеет. Планирует получить кредит для приобретения бычков. После чего бычки будут откармливаться и продаваться дороже , летом. Этот вид деятельности поможет ее семье, и развитию фермерской деятельности данной местности. Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 10 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Bufanala B Group

texts.en:
Rose Naiga is 35 years old and lives in Kalerwe, Uganda. She has a welding business and makes $25,000 Ugandan shillings—or about $15 U.S. dollars—a week, which is not enough to pay the mandatory school fees for her six children. They range in age from 2 to 18 years old.

That's why she has applied for a $1,100 loan with three other women. In a group loan, the funds are distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members guarantee each other's loans, so if one member can't repay, the others are responsible. Fida N. wants to grow her business, while Scovia B. wishes to start selling sweet potatoes. Lastly, Jawuda I. hopes to buy more clothes to expand her retail shop.

loans.use: To buy supplies to expand a welding business

loans.name: Davlat

texts.ru:
Davlat S., 41, lives in Vahdat, Tajikistan. He is married and has 4 children. Davlat is a cattle farmer. He plans to use this loan to purchase young bulls to be raised and then profitably resold a month later. Davlat has been in business for 10 years and cattle farming is his main source of income. He plans to repay this loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Саидов Давлат проживает в городе Вахдат. Возраст 41 год, женат, имеет 4 детей. Образование среднее. Занимается торговлей крупно рогатого скота. Планирует получить кредит для того чтобы купить молодых бычков. Он их откормит и через месяц продаст по более выгодной цене. Опыт в данной сфере у клиента 10 лет. Этот бизнес является основным источником дохода его семьи. Погасить клиент планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Koser's Group

texts.en:
I am Koser P.. I'm in my early forties and married with two kids. My son is in kindergarten, and my daughter is not of school age yet. Currently, my husband is employed in the food market selling fruit. He would like to start his own fruit business. I am confident that he will be able to do well because he has gained experience in this business.

Shahnaz B. is borrowing to expand her clothing business. Margaret B. plans to invest in her husband’s paint store. Basheeran B. hopes to use this loan for her husband’s plumbing business. All these women dream of a comfortable and sound economic future.

loans.use: Start fruit business

loans.name: Tweyambe A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Fida K.. She is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to expand business. Fida is 35 years old and is married with a husband who brews local beer. She has 5 children ranging from age 3 to 15 and her children go to school. Each week, Fida makes approximately UGX 10000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children . Fida has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 in order to purchase a weighing scale and the loan was paid back on time.

Fida is joined in her small group by Hadija K., Alisha N., Rebecca L., and Cate W.. Hadija K. has a business selling used clothes and wants to increase her stock of clothes. Alisha N. is currently operating a business in used clothing sales and wants a loan to start a new business. Rebecca L. operates a business of tailoring and wants to add to the business. Cate W. is currently in the business of selling used clothes and is requesting a loan to boost the clothing business.

loans.use: To boost retail shop business

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy S. is 35 years old, married with 4 children, and lives in Lagos State. She sells weavon, attachments and provisions. She has been in her business since 1987 and needs the loan amount of $775 to buy more attachments and weavon for sale.

loans.use: To buy more weaveon and attachments for sale

loans.name: Abdunosir

texts.ru:
Abdunosir F., 38, lives in Vahdat, Tajikistan. He is married and has 4 children. Abdunosir’s main occupation is a driver. In addition, he is farming cattle. Abdunosir plans to use this loan to purchase young bulls to be raised and then resold. Abdunosir plans to repay this loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Файзов Абдуносир Холбоевич житель города Вахдат.38 лет, женат имеет 4 детей. Образование среднее, по специальности водитель. Кроме того занимается животноводством, для чего и планирует получить кредит. Хочет купить молодых бычков для откормки и реализации. Этот вид деятельности поможет развитию фермерской деятельности, а также улучшить финансовое положение клиента. Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Tweyambe B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Sarah M.. She is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to increase capital. Sarah is 25 years old and is married. She has 4 children ranging from age 6 to 15 and her children go to school. Each week, Sarah makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to meet basic needs. Sarah has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to increase on stock and the loan was paid back on time.

Sarah is joined in her small group by Fida N., Efrance T., Justine N., and Faridah M.. Fida N. has a business in used clothing sales and wants to expand business. Efrance T. is currently operating a business running a bar and wants a loan to purchase a fridge. Justine N. operates a business of running a bar and wants to purchase a fridge. Faridah M. is currently in the business of charcoal selling and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of charcoal.

loans.use: To increase stock in shop

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Mrs. Aminata D. is a 30 year old married woman and mother of 4 children. She lives in a polygamous family with another one of her husband’s wives. Her husband, Mr. Bahama Soumaré, is a cattle farmer. From the youngest age, Aminata was already helping her parents in the cattle farming business and the marketing of milk. As a result, Aminata has mastered all the details of this activity.

Before joining the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso, Aminata was having trouble feeding her cows well. So she decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso through an association of interdependent (group) loans. After a two-year experience in the association, she moved on to an individual loan. She is now on her second loan. All the previous loans were properly paid back.

Mrs. Aminata D. stocks up in cattle feed (20 to 25 bags) in Bamako to be transported to Sanankoroba. Her herd consumes part of it, and the other part is sold to other cattle farmers. This operation is repeated every week.

On average, she makes a profit of 500 FCFA (~USD 1.5) per bag, or 40.000 FCFA (~USD 23) per month.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva volunteer.

• Madame Aminata D. est une femme mariée de 30 ans et mère de 04 enfants. Elle vit dans une famille polygame avec une coépouse. Son mari Mr Bahama Soumaré est éleveur. Dès son jeune age, elle aidait déjà ses parents dans les activités d’élevage et de commercialisations de lait. De ce fait Aminata maîtrise cette activité dans son détail et sa spécificité.

• Avant d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso, Madame Aminata avait des difficultés pour bien nourrir ses vaches qui ne pouvaient pas produire alors une quantité suffisante de lait pour la commercialisation. Ainsi elle a décidé d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso à travers une association de crédit solidaire. Après une expérience de deux ans en association, elle a passé au prêt individuel et est à son deuxième prêt. Tous les prêts précédents se sont correctement dénoués.

• Madame Aminata D. s’approvisionne en aliment bétail (20 à 25 sacs) à Bamako pour acheminer à Sanankoroba. Une partie est consommée par son troupeau et l’autre partie est vendue aux autres éleveurs. Cette opération est renouvelée chaque semaine.

• Elle réalise en moyenne un bénéfice de 500 FCFA (~USD 1,5) par sac soit 40.000 FCFA (~USD 23) par mois.

loans.use: Purchase of 20 to 25 bags of cattlefeed (cottonseed,feeding cake,bran, hay)

loans.name: Asghari's Group

texts.en:
I am Asghari N., the leader of a group of three other women: Haseena B., Sardaran B., and Samina B.. We have been together for almost a year and have always helped each other in times of need. In addition, we all are aware of the importance of hard work and exert a lot of effort to make our businesses prosper.

I have six kids, and my husband manufactures furniture. He has been in this business for more then 15 years. We would use the loan to buy wood in bulk. Haseena B. would use the loan for the family's business in second-hand items. Sardaran B. wants to purchase a rickshaw. Samina B. would invest the loan in the family’s fruit business.

loans.use: Buy wood in bulk

loans.name: Tweyambe C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Sylvia B.. She is currently in the business of selling used clothes and is requesting a loan to add to the business. Sylvia is 38 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has 6 children ranging from age 5 to 24 and her children go to school. Each week, Sylvia makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Sylvia has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to expand business and the loan was paid back on time.

Sylvia is joined in her small group by Fida N., Melda B., Jennifer N., and Aliya N.. Fida N. has a business in Jennifer Nabatanzi and wants to grocery store. Melda B. is currently operating a business in hotel and wants a loan to add in business. Jennifer N. operates a business of retail shop and wants to purchase a fridge. Aliya N. is currently in the business of selling used clothes and is requesting a loan to start a new business.

loans.use: To expand clothes business

loans.name: Marthe Evelyne

texts.fr:
Marthe Evelyne B. was born on July 28, 1968 in Cotonou.  Married, she is the mother of four.  She is a hairdresser by profession but also manages in parallel the sale of cosmetics, pagnes (colorful traditional cloth), and other items.  Since her business is located in the heart of Cotonou, the economic capitol of Benin, she has a large and demanding customer base. She asked for this loan to increase her market share and to respond to customer expectations.  
 Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer



Dame B. Marthe Evelyne est née  le 28 juillet 1968 à COTONOU. Mariée, elle est mère de 4 enfants. Elle est coiffeuse de profession mais mène parallèlement à cette formation la vente de produits cosmétiques, de pagnes et autres. Son lieu d’activité étant situé au cœur de  COTONOU, la capitale économique du BENIN, elle a une clientèle nombreuse et exigeante. Elle a demandé ce prêt pour augmenter sa part de marché et répondre aux attentes de sa clientèle.

loans.use: To buy 40 different braids, 20 bolts of HITARGET brand pagnes, cosmetics, and other beauty products

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Alidé - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Jumanazar

texts.ru:
Jumanazar H. lives in Qurgan-Tube. He is 50 years old, married and has 2 children. Jumanazar has a college degree in engineering. He works at hydroelectric power station Sangtuda. In addition, for 12 years, Jumanazar has been engaged in cattle farming. He buys, raises and then resells cattle at the local market. Jumanazar plans to use this loan to purchase additional animals. He plans to repay the loan within 6 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Хаитбоев Джуманазар житель города Курган- Тюбе. Возраст 50 лет , женат имеет 2 детей. Образование высшее, по специальности инженер. Работает на ГЭС Сангтуда. Кроме того занимается животноводством. Планирует получить кредит для покупки крупно рогатого скота. После покупки животных клиент откармливает их и перепродает жителям своей местности, что помогает покупателям и продавцу не тратить деньги на транспорт до рынка. Опыт в этой сфере клиент имеет 12 лет. Погасить кредит клиент планирует за 6 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase young bulls

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
My name is Nasreen S. from Multan, Pakistan. My husband is a rickshaw driver. His rickshaw is not in good condition, and he wants to replace it with a new one. The rickshaw is our only source of income, so we are in urgent need of this loan.

My fellow loan members also need loans: Rasheeda B. will use her share of the loan to pay off the remaining installments on their rickshaw; this early payment will save them some money. Rukkiah B. sells cloth. Parween B.’s husband runs an electric goods store. Yasmeen B. would use the loan to expand their wholesale betelnut business. All these women play a major role in earning income for their families.

loans.use: Replace old rickshaw with a new one

loans.name: Tweyambe D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rose Wamwendeki. She is currently in the business of running a drug shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more drugs to sell. Rose is 29 years old and is married. Her husband has a catering business. She has 6 children ranging from age 4 to 13 and her children go to school. Each week, Rose makes approximately UGX 10000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Rose has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to increase stock and the loan was paid back on time.

Rose is joined in her small group by Sarah M. and Betty M.. Sarah M. has a business running a retail shop and wants to start a wholesale business. Betty M. is a peasant farmer and wants a loan to expand business.

loans.use: To increase the stock of drugs and uplift business

loans.name: Tojinisso

texts.ru:
Tojinisso Zaydulayevna S., 35, is married and has 4 children. Tojinisso has a college degree. She lives in the town of Vakhdat where she teaches at the local secondary school. In addition, Tojinisso is engaged in cattle farming. She wants to take this loan to purchase a milk cow to provide milk for her family. Tojinisso plans to repay this loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Шерова Тоджиниссо Зайдуллаена проживает в городе Вахдат. Возраст 35 лет замужем, имеет 4 детей. Образование высшее. Работает Учителем средней школы. Занимается животноводством. На планируемый кредит хочет купить дойную корову для обеспечения семьи молоком. Погасить кредит клиентка планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

Madina has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to increase stock and the loan was paid back on time.

Madina is joined in her small group by Madina N.. Madina N. has a business selling sweet potatoes and wants to add to her stock.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Zebonisso.

texts.ru:
Zebonisso S., 41, is married and has 3 children. Zebonisso has a college degree. She lives in the town of Vakhdat where she teaches at the local secondary school. Zebonisso wants to take this loan to purchase a milk cow to provide milk for her family. Zebonisso plans to repay this loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Шерова Зебониссо проживает в городе Вахдат. Возраст 41 год, замужем имеет 3 детей. Образование высшее. Работает учителем в средней школе.Хочет получить кредит для приобретения дойной коровы, чтобы обеспечит семью молоком. Погасить кредит клиентка планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase a milk cow

loans.name: Namayira Centre B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Christine Z.. She is currently in the business of running a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to purchase a hair dryer. Christine is 37 years old and is married. Her husband is a mechanic. She has 5 children ranging from age 7 to 18 and her children go to school. Each week, Christine makes approximately UGX 80000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Christine has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 180000 in order to increase stock and the loan was paid back on time.

Christine is joined in her small group by Rose N., Beth G., Ruth B., and Sarah N.. Rose N. has a business running a salon and wants to buy more salon equipment. Beth G. is currently operating a grocery store business and wants a loan to increase stock. Ruth B. operates a business of a drug shop and wants to expand business. Sarah N. is currently in the business of running a hotel and is requesting a loan to add to the business.

loans.name: Nkechi

texts.en: Nkechi A. is 40 years old, married with 4 children and hails from Iba Area of Lagos State Nigeria. She sells building materials including sand, rod and granite. She needs the loan in the amount of $775 to buy more building materials for sale.

loans.use: To buy more building materials for sale

loans.name: Djélika

texts.fr:
Mrs. Djélika Traoré is a 29 year old married woman and mother of 2 boys (10 and 8 years old), both attending school. She lives with her husband in a polygamous family with her husband’s other wife and his parents.

Mrs. Konaté Djélika Traoré abandoned her schooling very early on and quickly devoted herself to commercial pursuits, notably catering. She has12 years of experience in this business and masters all the aspects of the catering business.

Mrs. Djélika Traoré runs a restaurant across from an industrial cotton processing plant, and on the edge of an international road to the Ivory Coast. The restaurant is specialized in the preparation of fast meals (rice plates, potatoes, plantain, spaghetti etc…) intended for workingman and truck drivers for breakfast and lunch. Her purchases are renewed every time her stock goes below a certain level. She stocks up in Bamako (the capital of Mali) and in Siskasso (the 3rd administrative area of Mali).

Mrs. Konaté Djélika Traoré has been working with the microfinance institution Soro Yriwaso for the last seven (7) years. She started out with an interdependent [group] loan (in a women’s association) before qualifying for an individual loan. The amount of her loan went from 75.000 FCFA (~USD 166) to 450.000 FCFA (~USD 1000) her current loan. All the loans have been properly repaid.

She manages her business all year long without noteworthy problems. Mrs. Berthé takes in, on average, 50.000 CFA (~USD 111) a day, with a daily profit of 6.000 (~USD 13). With her profit, she provides for the most part of her expenses and helps her husband cover the expenses of the family (health, education, food etc…).

n.b. =Mrs. Djélika Traoré is seen with her employee on the photo

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva volunteer.

• Madame Djélika Traoré est une femme mariée de 29 ans, mère de 02 garçons (10 ans et 08 ans) inscrits à l’école. Elle vit avec son mari dans une famille polygame avec une coépouse et les parents de son mari. • Ayant vite abandonné l’école dès son jeune Madame Konaté Djélika Traoré s’est vite adonnée aux activités commerciales notamment la restauration. Avec une expérience de 12 ans dans cette activité, elle maîtrise tous les aspects de la restauration.

• Madame Djélika Traoré exploite un restaurant en face d’une unité industrielle de traitement de coton et au bord d’une route internationale en direction de la république de Cote d’Ivoire. Le restaurant est spécialisé dans la conception de plats rapides (Plats de riz, de pomme de terre, de banane Plantin, de Spaghetti etc…) destinés aux ouvriers et aux chauffeurs routiers pour le petit déjeuner et le déjeuner. Ses achats de stock sont renouvelés chaque fois qu’elle diminue d’un certain niveau. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako (la capitale du Mali et à Sikasso (la 3e Région administrative du Mali)

• Madame Konaté Djélika Traoré travaille avec l’Institution de Microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis sept (07) ans. Elle a commencé avec le crédit solidaire (Dans une association de femmes) avant d’obtenir un prêt individuel. Son montant de prêt a passé de 75.000 FCFA (~USD 166) à 450.000 FCFA (~USD 1000) son prêt actuel. Tous les prêts se sont correctement dénoués.

• Elle mène son activité durant toute l’année sans difficultés notables. Madame Berthé réalise en moyenne un chiffre d’affaire de 50.000 CFA (~USD 111) par jour pour un bénéfice journalier de 6.000 (~USD 13). Avec les bénéfices réalisés elle assure l’essentiel de ses dépenses et aide son mari à assurer les dépenses de la famille (Santé, Education, Nourriture etc…).

nb =Madame Djélika Traoré est avec son employe sur la photo

loans.use: Purchase of 1 ton of rice, three (3) 20-liter  jugs of oil, beverage racks, various spices.

loans.name: Namayira Centre C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Mariam K.. She is currently in the business of running a hotel and is requesting a loan to expand business. Mariam is 40 years old and is married. She has 6 children ranging from age 7 to 22 and her children go to school. Each week, Mariam makes approximately UGX 140000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to meet basic needs. Mariam has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to increase stock and the loan was paid back on time.

Mariam is joined in her small group by Nakato N., Jesca F. and Ruth N.. Nakato N. has a business selling used clothes and wants to increase stock. Jesca F. is currently operating a business running a bar and wants a loan to purchase a fridge. Ruth N. operates a business of selling matooke and wants to expand business.

loans.use: To expand hotel business

loans.name: Nadezhda

texts.en:
Nadezhda is married and has two grownup children. She lives in Melitopol, Ukraine, and owns a small business in the central city market. A skilled entrepreneur, wife, and mother, Nadezhda is dedicated to the growth and the success of her business. For the past ten years, she has sold sportswear and footwear in the central city market. The combination of an ideal location and skillful product presentation make Nadezhda’s vending kiosk a point of attraction in the market. Her kindness, skill, and outgoing personality have helped her to develop a loyal customer base. With strong character and a desire to see her business grow, Nadezhda has maintained a perfect credit history with Nadiya Ukraine for the past 7 years. 

Currently, Nadezhda has $2,000 of goods in inventory. Her turnover capital is about $1,800 and her monthly net profit is approximately $600. Nadezhda is seeking a loan of $1,000 to increase her inventory. With additional income from her profits, Nadezhda hopes to continue to improve her family’s standard of living. Moreover, profit generated by her business will give Nadezhda a chance to pay for her son’s education at one of the local colleges.

loans.use: To increase inventory and the assortment of goods

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is married and has two kids. She and her family live in Nikopol. Nataliya sells souvenirs, gifts and cosmetics in the local market. Her prices are always reasonable and her attitude towards her customers is very friendly. Nataliya has been in business for 8 years. Her trade has been characterized by stability and consistent growth. Currently, Nataliya has about $8,000 of goods in inventory and her monthly profit is approximately $700.

Nataliya is seeking a loan of $900 to increase her inventory and to generate additional profit. She is hoping to see her venture grow and is planning to buy at least one more vending facility in the market. Nataliya is very good with her finances: she knows how to manage money and makes sound investments. This loan will allow her to maintain a good product selection, which will in turn allow her to earn sufficient income to support herself and her family.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy B. is a mother of 5, is 40 years old, and hails from the Iba Area of Lagos State. She is a cosmetologist and also sells hair weaves. She has been in business since 1992 and needs the loan amount of $875 to buy more hair weaves and hair cream for sale.

loans.use: To buy more hair weaves and hair cream for sale

loans.name: Namayira Centre E Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Fatuma M.. She is currently in the business of selling sweet potatoes and is requesting a loan to increase stock. Fatuma is 20 years old and is married. Her husband has a wholesale business. She has 4 children ranging from age 5 to 16 and her children go to school. Each week, Fatuma makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Fatuma has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 180000 in order to increase stock and the loan was paid back on time.

Fatuma is joined in her small group by Ayubu N., Tapie I. and Jiida N.. Ayubu N. has a business in trading pigs and wants to expand business. Tapie I. is currently operating a business in poultry keeping and wants a loan to purchase more poultry feeds. Jiida N. operates a business of art and craft sales and wants to add in craft business.

loans.use: To purchase more sacks of sweet potatoes and increase stock

loans.name: Vasif

texts.en: Vasif K. is a 43-year-old married man and he has two children. He lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Vasif and his wife (who is pictured) run the family business together. Vasif's wife cares for their only cow, while Vasif sells the cow's milk in town. Unfortunately, the income generated from the one cow is insufficient to support the family. Therefore, he is seeking a loan of $500 from the Norwegian Microcredit Saatli branch to buy one more pure-bred cow, which would increase the business's monthly income. In the Caucasus region the price of a good cow is approximately $800-$1,000, so he would supplement the money he hopes to receive from the the Norwegian Microcredit Saatli branch with his own funds to enable him to purchase another cow.

loans.use: To purchase another pure-bred cow

loans.name: Rada

texts.en:
Rada is married and has one child. She lives in Nikopol and runs a small business in the central city market selling clothing and footwear. Her kiosk at the market has a very favorable location. Rada has been in this trade for 4 years. Presently, she has about $6,000 of goods in inventory and her monthly net profit is approximately $600. 

Nadiya Ukraine has previously assisted Rada with other loans. She seeks an additional loan of $600 for two purposes: she needs to purchase additional inventory for her current business, and she would also like to use some money to open a second sales kiosk to sell clothing items and shoes. She is hoping that by expanding her overall business enterprise and moving into a new area of retail she will be able to increase her income and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to open a new vending facility

loans.name: Namayira Centre F Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Irene A.. She is currently in the business of local beer brewing and is requesting a loan to expand business. Irene is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a teacher. She has 5 children ranging from age 2 to 17 and her children go to school. Each week, Irene makes approximately UGX 35000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to meet basic needs. Irene has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to increase stock and the loan was paid back on time.

Irene is joined in her small group by Tapie M., Edith A. and Siida N. . Tapie M. has a business running a retail shop and wants to purchase a fridge. Edith A. is currently operating a business in used clothing sales and wants a loan to increase stock. Siida N. sells art and craft and wants to boost her craft business.

loans.use: To add to brew business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity O. is 38 years old, married with 5 children, she hails from Iba in Lagos State. She is a fashion designer. She learnt her trade in 3 years. She has been in business for 4 years. She needs the loan of $875 to buy more cloth for sale.

loans.use: To buy more cloth for sale

loans.name: Sevinj

texts.en: Sevinj A. is a 28-year-old married woman and she has one child. She lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. She has a small herd of milk cows, from which she sells 60 liters of milk per day to the local milk processing shop and to the supermarket. The demand for milk is strong so she firmly believes that she could sell more milk if she had a larger herd of cattle. Therefore, she is seeking a loan of $600 from the Normicro Saatli branch so that she can purchase another calf for breeding purposes to increase her monthly income.

loans.use: To increase the number of cattle in her herd

loans.name: Iyetunde

texts.en: Iyetunde A. is 40 years old, married and has a child. She hails from Iba Area in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells drinks. She needs a loan of $450 to enable her buy more drinks for sale. She has been in business for 4 years. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more drinks for sale

loans.name: Favour

texts.en: Favour H. is 32 years old and is married with 3 children. She hails from the Iba Area of Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells clothes and baby wares. She has been in her business since 2004. She needs the loan amount of $450 to buy baby wares and clothes for sale.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and baby wares for sale

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.fr:
Mrs. Elisabeth Djoné is a 46 year old married woman. She is the mother of 7 children (the oldest is 26 and the youngest 6 years old). Of her 7 children, six are in school. She lives with her husband and some of her children in the village of Mana.

Elisabeth’s main activity is market gardening. She has over ten (10) years of experience in this field and she has mastered all the market gardening methods. In the three hectares she works just behind her house, she grows lettuce, onions, cabbage, chili, tomato, and eggplant. She has also planted a lot of papaya shoots. This production is sold off in the market of Ouelessebougou, a town close to Elisabeth’s village, except for the chili, which are sold in Bamako (the capital of Mali). This activity generates a profit of 120.000 FCFA (~USD 267) per cycle of market gardening (six months period). For each weekly transaction Elisabeth makes an average net profit of 35.000 FCFA 35.000 FCFA (~USD 78) or 140.000 FCFA (~USD 312) per month.

Mrs. Elisabeth Djoné is on her 16th loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. She started with an interdependent (group) loan in a women’s association before qualifying for an individual loan. All the loans have been properly repaid. Elisabeth is the initiator of the involvement of over 40 women in the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso.

With the profit she makes, Elisabeth provides for most of the household expenses and takes care of the school fees of three of her children who are in a secondary school in Bamako (the capital of Mali). Finally, she has been able to buy an animal drawn cart.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva volunteer.

• Madame Elisabeth Djoné est une femme mariée de 46 ans, mère de 07 enfants (le plus âgé à 26 ans et le plus petit à 06 ans). Sur les sept enfants six fréquentent l’école. Elle vit avec son mari et une partie de ses enfants dans le village de Mana.

• Elle exerce le maraîchage comme activité principale. Disposant d’une expérience de plus de dix (10) ans dans le domaine cité, elle maîtrise toutes les techniques du maraîchage. Dans les trois hectares exploités juste derrière sa maison, elle y cultive de la salade, des oignons, des choux, du piment, de la tomate, de l’aubergine. En plus elle a planté beaucoup de pied de Papaye. Cette production est écoulée sur le marché de Ouelessebougou (localité proche du village de résidence d’Elisabeth) sauf pour le piment qui est vendu à Bamako (la capitale du Mali). Cette activité engendre un bénéfice de 120.000 FCFA (~USD 267) par cycle de maraîchage (durée six mois).

Pour chaque opération hebdomadaire, Madame Elisabeth réalise en moyenne un bénéfice net de 35.000 FCFA 35.000 FCFA (~USD 78) soit 140.000 FCFA (~USD 312) par mois.

• Madame Elisabeth Djoné est à son 16e prêt avec l’Institution de Microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elle a commencé avec le crédit solidaire (Dans une association de femmes) avant d’obtenir un prêt individuel. Tous les prêts se sont correctement dénoués. Elle est à l’origine de l’intégration de plus de 40 femmes dans le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso.

• Avec les bénéfices réalisés elle assure l’essentiel des dépenses de la famille et assure les frais d’éducation scolaires de trois de ses enfants qui fréquentent actuellement des écoles supérieures à Bamako (capitale du Mali). Enfin elle a pu acheté une charrette à traction animale.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds (potato and other), gardening tools, fertilizers and manpower for market gardening

loans.name: Javanshir

texts.en: Javanshir A. is a 35-year-old married man and he has one child. He lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Javanshir has seven pedigree milk cows, from which he sells 100 liters of milk per day to the local milk processing shop. Unfortunately, his current income is insufficient to renovate and expand his cow shed, so he hopes to receive $500 from the Normicro Saatli branch to do just that. If this loan comes to fruition, he plans on applying for a second loan to increase the number of cattle in his herd.

loans.use: To renovate and expand his cow shed (and, later, to purchase additional cattle)

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline A. is a mother of 6, is 40 years old, and hails from the Ighando Area of Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells drinks, juices, wine, and provisions. She has been in business since 2002. She needs the loan amount of $875 to buy more drinks for sale.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and provisions for sale

loans.name: Blessing Bassey

texts.en: Blessing Bassey K. is married and 35 years old. She hails from Lagos State, Nigeria. She has been in business since 2004. She sells cloth. She needs the loan amount of $1,200 to buy more cloth for sale.

loans.use: To buy cloth for sale

loans.name: Rokia

texts.fr:
Mrs. Rokia Traoré is a 52 year old married woman, mother of 4 children. She lives with her husband and her children in N’Tentou in the town of Ouelessebougou. Her husband is a retired serviceman and does not have a sufficient income to cover the household expenses.

Mrs. Traoré abandoned her schooling very early on and took up commercial activities, notably various kinds of trading. However, she has always been brought face to face with the lack of financial means to undertake a large economic endeavor. Upon her husband’s retirement, the family moved to Ouelessebougou, not far from the premises of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. After inquiring she started to take up loans with Soro Yiriwaso through an association before being able to take out an individual loan. She has now taken 7 loans with Soro Yiriwaso.

Mrs. Rokia Traoré’s family has a store where she stocks cereal bags before reselling them wholesale or retail. She stocks up on the local markets of Dankassa, Sankama, Keleya, Selingué, Faraba, Sidoba and of Ouelessebougou. She carries out a market survey before going to Bamako and selling to wholesalers. Her profit margin is on average 3.000 FCFA (~USD 6) per bag. Her monthly profit is 150.000 FCFA (~USD 333). With the profit she makes, she provides for the most part of the household expenses (health, education, food, etc…)

Her main concern is to properly reimburse the loan from Soro Yiriwaso. She hopes to increase the amount of her loan to increase the size of her business and thus realize more profit.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva volunteer.

• Madame Rokia Traoré est une femme mariée de 52 ans, mère de 04 enfants. Elle vit avec son mari et ses enfants à N’Tentou dans la ville de Ouelessebougou. Son mari un ancien militaire est à la retraite et ne dispose pas de ressources financières suffisantes pour assurer les charges familiales. • Ayant vite abandonné l’école dès son jeune Madame Traoré s’est vite adonnée aux activités commerciales notamment le commerce divers. Cependant elle a toujours été confrontée au manque de moyen financier pour mener une activité économique d’une grande taille. A la retraite de son mari, la famille s’est installée à Ouelessebougou non loin des locaux de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Après renseignement elle a commencé à prendre des prêts avec Soro Yiriwaso au sein d’une association avant d’arriver au prêt individuel. Elle est à son 7e prêt avec Soro Yiriwaso. • Madame Rokia Traoré dispose d’un magasin dans sa famille où elle stocke ses sacs de céréales avant de les vendre en gros ou en détail. Elle s’approvisionne sur les marchés des localités de Dankassa, Sankama, de Keleya, de Selingué, de Faraba, de Sidoba et de Ouelessebougou. Elle procède à une prospection de marché à Bamako avant d’y aller les vendre à des grossistes. Sa marge bénéficiaire est en moyenne de 3.000 FCFA (~USD 6) par sac. Son bénéfice mensuel est de 150.000 FCFA (~USD 333). Avec les bénéfices réalisés elle assure l’essentiel des dépenses de la famille (Santé, Education, Nourriture etc…). • Son premier souci est de rembourser correctement le prêt de Soro Yiriwaso. Elle espère augmenter le montant de son prêt pour accroître la taille de son affaire et réaliser ainsi plus de bénéfice.

loans.use: Purchase - Stocking and Sale of various cereals (millet, corn, peanut) and Nitta nuts.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in merchandise for her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Continue investing in seafood at wholesale prices

loans.name: Tereza

texts.en:
Tereza has been selling bedspreads for eight months in El Cacique community of Yamasá. She is twenty-seven years old and has four children. Her husband lives outside the country and visits the family only rarely. Tereza says her business is very profitable because she buys a bedspread at 600 Dominican pesos and resells it at about 1000 pesos or more (USD 1.00 = 34 pesos).

Until now, the entrepreneur has been running her business out of her rented house but she says she will keep doing business in order that she can finish her own house which is being built in the same community. Tereza will use her loan to purchase more bedspreads in order to increase her income.

loans.use: Purchase of a large quantity of bedspreads to resell in her community

loans.name: Saidat

texts.en: Saidat A. is 28 years old, is married, and has 2 children. She hails from the Mushin Area of Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells bags of flour, rice, and beans. She has been in business since 1998. She needs the loan amount of $700 to buy more bags for sale.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, flour, and beans for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy 2 cases of clothing for resale.

payments.comment: El pago real es de $37.50 dólares.
El pago real es de $ 37.50 dólares.
La cuota real es de $ 37.50 dólares.

loans.name: Bolale

texts.en: Bolale O. is 45 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in the Mushin Area of Lagos State. She sells provisions and drinks; she has been in her business since 1997. She needs the loan amount of $450 to buy more provisions and drinks for sale.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and drinks for sale

loans.name: María Antonia

texts.en:
María Antonia is a forty-six-year-old, experienced businesswoman and mother of three children. María is a well-known seamstress in El Cacique community of Yamasá, seeing that she has been working there for more than twenty years. Five years ago, María Antonia decided to take advantage of her reputation and opened her own shop in a locale she had bought beforehand. The entrepreneur says that she has a well-established clientele, the majority of whom are parents of school-going children. María also explains that she has a monthly income of about US$ 250.

When she is overburdened and has many orders, she hires other experienced women temporarily to help her. María plans on using her loan to buy special cloth to start producing bedspreads, pillows, and cushions because these products are in high demand in her community.

María’s business supports her children’s university studies.

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of cloth in order to produce bedspreads, pillows, and cushions.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy more merchandise and begin remodeling

loans.name: Brigida

texts.en:
Brigida is in her late fifties and she is the mother of four children. She has been separated from her husband for more than fifteen years. Since then, she has been working hard to lift her family up out of poverty. Brigida runs a liquor store which a large number of people visit day and night to purchase beer, wine, whisky, energizing beverages, and other alcoholic drinks. Brigida explains that ‘Presidente’ (the principal Dominican beer) is the most sold because "people consider it the best beer of the world and drink it as if it were water."

Brigida hopes that her business will help her buy her own house sooner or later. With her loan, the entrepreneur will buy more drinks to satisfy her customers’ needs.

loans.use: To purchase beverages for a liquor store

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina is a thirty-five-year-old single mom, raising her six children on her own. Josefina owns and operates a general store which people in the neighborhood visit to get a large variety of goods such as rice, beans, fresh vegetables, milk, eggs, rum, beer and so forth. Josefina operates the business in a rented locale but she wants to have her own house so that her family can live at ease.

With her loan, Josefina will replenish her store since supplies are running low.

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of many goods to replenish her general store

loans.name: Aura María

texts.es:
For twelve years Mrs. Aura P. has worked in the seamstress business making clothes for all sizes and all ages. She owns her own market stand, which was a costly investment. She puts all of her effort into every day's work because of that investment and because her business is her family's only source of income.

The business started with few clients but with the passing time has grown as she has brought in new clients and has been recognized in the village of El Sauce.

It is important to point out tha Aura has taken out 6 loans with Ceprodel. The loans have had a great impact; she has improved both her sewing machinery and her quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Desde hace 12 años en la ciudad de Leon específicamente en el pueblo de El Sauce, la señora Aura P. se dedica al negocio de costura de todo tamaño y para todas las edades. Posee un tramo propio el cual le ha costado mucha inversión y por ser el único sustento de su hogar se esfuerza día a día en este trabajo.

El negocio lo comienza con pocos clientes pero a medida que el tiempo transcurre ha ido mejorando su condición tanto así que ha adquirido nuevos clientes y además ha sido muy reconocida en el pueblo de El Sauce.

Es necesario destacar que la señora Aura ha realizado 6 créditos en Ceprodel que le han impactado grandemente por el hecho de que ha mejorado sus maquinaria para la costura y además ha mejorado su nivel de vida.

loans.use: Purchase cloth

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice O. is 54 years old, is married with 5 children, and hails from Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells provisions and drinks. She has been in business since 2000. She needs the loan amount of $450 to buy more provisions and drinks for sale.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and drinks for sale

loans.name: Modunat

texts.en: Modunat O. is 45 years old, is married with 6 children, and hails from the Mushin Area of Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells building and furniture materials. She has been in this business since 2000. She needs the loan of $450 to buy more building and furniture materials for sale.

loans.use: To buy more building and furniture materials

loans.name: Funke

texts.en: Funke M. is 30 years old, is married, and has 5 children. She hails from the Mushin Area in Lagos State. She sells drink and provisions. She has been in her business since 2004. She is seeking a loan of $450 to buy more provisions and drinks for sale.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and drinks for sale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary O. is 38 years old, is married with 3 children, and hails from the Mushin Area in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells motor parts. She has been in business since 2005. She needs the loan amount of $450 to buy more motor parts for sale.

loans.use: To buy more motor parts for sale

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en: Taiwo A. is a mother of 3, is 42 years old, and hails from the Mushin Area in Lagos State. She sells drinks and sachet water. She has been in her business for the past 18 years. She needs the loan of $450 to buy more drinks for sale.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and sachet water for sale

loans.name: Chepa

texts.es:
Chepa has a stall where she sells groceries and all types of preserves. Her residence is located in zone '8th of December' of the city of La Paz and her stall is located in the zone of Tembladerani, close to the Bolívar market in the Western Slope of the city of La Paz. This is the tenth time that she has requested a loan with Impro. Her credit record qualifies her as a good client since the repayment of the loans that she has completed were within the dates established in the contracts. The loan that she now requests will be used for the purchase of merchandise in large quantities in order to reduce costs. Her previous loans permit us to agree to this loan since she has experience as a merchant and all the previous loans were paid in a punctual manner.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Chepa tiene un puesto donde vende abarrotes y toda clase de conservas. Su domicilio se encuentra ubicado en la zona 8 de diciembre de la ciudad de La Paz y su puesto esta ubicado en la zona de Tembladerani, cerca al mercado Bolívar en la Ladera Oeste de la ciudad de La Paz. Es la Décima vez que solicita un crédito en Impro; su historial lo califica como cliente bueno ya que las cancelaciones que realiza son dentro de las fechas establecidas en los contratos. El crédito que ahora solicita será destinado para la compra de mercadería en cantidad para de esta manera abaratar los costos. Su antecedente crediticio le permite acceder a este crédito ya que tiene experiencia como comerciante y todos los créditos anteriores los pagó en forma puntual.

loans.use: To purchase groceries and preserves in large quantities for resale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Musilimot

texts.en: Musilimot O. is 50 years old; she is married with 4 children and hails from Lagos State. She sells kerosene. She has been in business since 1997. She needs the loan amount of $450 to buy more kerosene for sale.

loans.use: To buy more kerosene for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a new vehicle to use as a taxi

loans.name: Honorio

texts.es:
Honorio has a workshop where he creates leather footwear for women and works with an employee. His residence is located in the Tembladerani zone of the Western Slope of the city of La Paz. He has three children and his wife is a merchant. This is the fifth time that he has requested a loan from Impro and his record qualifies as him as a good client: that is to say he has a good record of compliance in the repayment of his loans. The loan will be used for the purchase of materials (leather, soles, heels, glue and pvc). His previous credit record permit us to agree to this loan since he has experience as an artisan. He has been a client of IMPRO since the year 2005.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Honorio tiene un taller donde elabora calzados de cuero para mujer y trabaja con un empleado. Su domicilio se encuentra ubicado en la zona de Tembladerani Ladera Oeste de la ciudad de La Paz. Tiene Tres hijos y su esposa es comerciante. Es la Quinta vez que solicita un crédito en Impro y su historial lo califica como cliente 1 es decir con cumplimiento bueno en el pago de su crédito. El crédito será destinado para la compra de de materia prima (cuero, planta, suela, tacos, clefa y pvc). Su antecedente crediticio le permite acceder a este crédito ya que tiene experiencia como artesano. Es cliente de IMPRO desde el año 2005.

loans.use: To buy materials such as leather, soles, glue and heels to make footwear.
