He started his business in 2001, when he purchased one cow with money he had saved up. The income from this business is not enough to cover all the family and business expenditures. Usubali purchases calves, breeds them, and sells them to the butcher, who works in the local market. To increase his profit margin, Usubali has to invest some money to make his small herd bigger. His application to Normicro Saatli branch for a $500 loan is approved already.  He hopes eventually to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy calves

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Ms. Amina has a very low income. She is 55, married, with five children, and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in Caucasus region.

Amina owns a herd of milk cows. Every day she sells milk to the local milk-processing shop. Her children help her breed cows in the nearby grazing field. The income from her four cows is too low to support the family or to increase her number of cows. That’s why Amina has applied to Norwegian Microcredit Saatli branch for $600 loan, to buy one more pure-bred cow to make her monthly income higher. The price of a milk calf is $300, and the cost of breeding is $100. The other $100 she plans to save for unexpected expenditures.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Biorifa

texts.ru:
Biorifa is 18 years old. She helps her father take care of the cattle. Her mother has gone to Russia to earn money for the family. Currently she has 6 rams and would like to purchase a few more. Purchasing cattle during the winter is very profitable because animals sell for cheaper. Biorifa lives in the Utkonos village in the Gafurovsk region. Most people in this area earn their income by raising and selling cattle.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Биорифа девушка котрой 18 лет ,она помогает отцу по уходу за скотом.Ее мать уехала в Россию на заработки.Биорифа имеет на данный момент 6 баранов, хочет попробовать купить еще .В зимнее время для скотоводов очень выгодно закупить скот , т.к сейчас дешево.Проживает Биорифа в Гафуровском районе в поселке Утконсой,в этом районе почти все жители живут за счет откорма и продажи скота.

loans.use: Cattle raising

loans.name: Zhulfi

texts.en: Zhulfi is a very low-income man. He is 52, married, and has five children. Zhulfi lives with his parents in the village of Saatli city in the central part of Azerbaijan Republic. He has a herd of five cows. He started his business five years ago with one cow, and he has increased the number of animals in the herd to five. Now he has applied to Normicro Saatli branch for a  $600 loan to build an open shed for his cattle.

loans.use: To build an open shed

loans.name: Zuhra

texts.ru:
Zuhra A. lives in the city of Somgar. She is 31 and has 3 children. She has been raising cattle for the past 10 years. She currently owns 6 cows 2 of which are milk cows. Zuhra milks the cows twice a day and obtains 5 liters of milk in the morning and 5 in the evening from each cow. In this way she obtains 20 liters of milk per day. She uses the milk to make kifir and sower cream, that she sells in the market. She wishes to use the loan to purchase 2 additional cows.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva Volunteer

Зухра Абдушукурова проживает в Сомгаре , возрост 31 год имеет 3 детей .Уже 10 лет как занимается уходом и откормом скота.На данный момент имеет 6 коров из которых 2 буренки дающщие молоко.Зухра в день 2 раза доит корову с которой получает 5 литров утором с одной и 5 литров вечером.В общем имеет в день 20 шлитров молока.Из молока она заготавливает домашний кифир и сметану,которые продает оптом на базаре.Получив займ хочет купить еще 2 коровы.

loans.use: Cattle raising

loans.name: Nigora

texts.ru:
Nigora H. is 33 years old, married and has 3 children. Her main earnings come from selling the traditional food named kurut (distantly resembles cottage cheese). In her free time she helps her husband take care of the cattle. The Hudoikulov family owns 10 rams. Nigora uses their wool to make yarn, which she sells on the market. She wants to obtain 5 more rams while the price of these animals is still low. She plans to raise the animals and in a few months sell them for a profit.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Худойкулова Нигора возрост 33 года имеет 3 детей .Сама основной доход имеет с продажи национального курута , а в свободное время помогает мужу по уходу за скотом.Семья Худойкуловых имеет 10 баранов,из шерсти которых Нигора прядет прядь.И также продает на базаре. Сейчас пока скот дешевый она взяв займ хочет купить еще 5 баранов.Через пару месяцев откормив продать с прибылью.

loans.use: Raising cattle

loans.name: Ntinda East A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Alice W.. She is currently in the business of used clothing sales and is requesting a loan to expand the business to bulk selling. Alice is 38 years old and is married. Her husband is a cloth seller. She has 4 children ranging from age 6 months to 10 and her children go to school. Each week, Alice makes approximately UGX 15000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children and start a poultry business. Alice has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 in order to invest in her cloth business and the loan was paid back on time.

Alice is joined in her small group by Solome K., Kasega J., Salama M., and Rebecca N.. Solome K. has a business in rice selling and wants to start an ice cream business. Kasega J. is currently operating a business running a retail shop and wants a loan to boost business. Salama M. operates a business of brick making and wants to boost business. Rebecca N. is currently in the business of charcoal selling and is requesting a loan to add more capital to the charcoal business.

loans.use: To expand clothe business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Ntinda East B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Salama N.. She is currently in the business of used clothing sales and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Salama is 32 years old and is a widow. She has 3 children ranging from age 8 to 12 and her children go to school. Each week, Salama makes approximately UGX 35000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to re-invest in the business and pay school fees for the children. Salama has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to invest in her cloth business and the loan was paid back on time.

Salama is joined in her small group by Alice K., Aisha B., Rehema N., and Teddy N.. Alice K. has a business of running a retail shop and wants to purchase more shop items. Aisha B. is currently operating a business running a school and wants a loan to construct more classrooms and buildings. Rehema N. operates a business of selling old clothes and wants to add stock. Teddy N. is currently in the business of chicken rearing and is requesting a loan to construct a poultry house.

loans.use: To add capital to cloth business and uplift it

loans.name: Ntinda East C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Betty N.. She is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan to boost business. Betty is 38 years old and is divorced. She has 3 children ranging from age 5 to 9 and her children go to school. Each week, Betty makes approximately UGX 49000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Betty has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 600000 in order to invest in her retail shop and the loan was paid back on time.

Betty is joined in her small group by Maria K., Aisha N., Betty N., and Sarah K.. Maria K. has a business in poultry keeping and wants to buy broiler mash. Aisha N. is currently operating a business in trading produce and wants a loan to add more capital to the business. Betty N. operates a business of running a retail shop and wants to add more capital to the business. Sarah K. is currently in the business of poultry and is requesting a loan to buy broiler mash.

loans.use: Increase stock in retail shop

loans.name: Sun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sun SaoR., 34, is a vendor selling a variety of grocery products in the Srass Keo commune part of Kampong Chnang province. Everyday she gains around $3 a day of profit from her sales. To supplement her standard of living, her husband Mr. Sim Sopheap, 39, works as a taxi-driver making on average $5 a day of profit. This couple has two childR. who are students. They strongly believe that their business would improve if they have a loan from Kiva org.

To improve their businesses and to make them successful, this couple categorizes the loan into 2 parts. First, they want to use this loan to purchase more groceries and sell them in large amounts. Second, they need to expand the business. With the principal’s plan they hope that their business will reach the target and gain more profit.

They will use the profit to send their child to a university. In conclusion, Sun and her family are grateful and appreciative for your trust and support.

loans.use: Sun would like to use this loan to purchase more groceries and sell them in large amounts.

loans.name: Namuwaya Central A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Annet N.. She is currently in the business of poultry and is requesting a loan to buy poultry feed and boost business. Annet is 22 years old and is single. Each week, Annet makes approximately UGX 12000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a new house. Annet has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to bought more chicks and the loan was paid back on time.

Annet is joined in her small group by Saijalia N., Mariam N., Irene S., and Ruth N.. All of them have bakery businesses and want to use the loan to add capital and expand them.

loans.use: To add to poultry business and boost it

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Farhod

texts.en: T. Farhod is 34 years old and he is married and has 3 children. Mr. T. started his business from scratch 7 years ago. Now he has his own trade outlet in the flea bazaar  thanks to some  business development loans from MicroInvest. Mr. T. is engaged in selling beauty supplies;  (hair dye/tint, creams, shampoo, soaps, scents and etc). He has a large assortment and many repeat customers. Now Mr. T. requests the loan of 2500 STJ to grow his business and increase his inventory because he has stiff competition.

loans.use: the business and assortment wideness

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en: Rehema M. is a single woman living with her mother. She has a timber business. She wants to expand her business by taking a loan from BRAC Tanzania.

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Neth

texts.en: Mrs. Neth C. T., 27, is married with three children and is a housewife who stays at home to look after the children and cook food for her family. To supplement their living condition, her husband Mr. Ngov Leang Nghy, 36, works as a motor-taxi driver and he normally makes on average around $4 a day of profit. This couple hopes to use this loan to purchase a new motor-bike for their son to use as a motor-taxi driver to sustain the standard of living. When the business goes forward and it provides more benefits, this couple will use the money to run another business by opening a grocery stand. Moreover, Mrs. Chanthu will bring all her children to school. Finally, this couple would like to thank for all lenders who contribute the capital to make their business grow.

loans.use: Neth would like to purchase a new motor-bike for her son to use as a motor-taxi driver to sustain their standard of living.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more hotel equipment

loans.name: Unsun

texts.en: Z. Unsun was born in 1967 in the J.Rasulov region and she is married and has 3 children. Mrs. Z. has been an active client of  MicroInvest since 2004. She first applied  for a business development loan because she was in a hard situation. She used to sell small wares but in time she started a business selling tea. Now she sells different sorts of  tea that she buys from wholesalers. Now Mrs. Z. requests the loan of 3500 STJ to import a new batch of tea.

loans.use: To import a new batch of tea.

loans.name: Ol

texts.en: Mrs. Ol C., 30, works as a grocery vendor normally earning on average $5 a day of profit. Her husband Mr. Vong Vy, 29, works as a farmer and he generally earns around $2 a day. This couple hopes to use this loan to purchase more groceries to sell in large amounts. At the same time, they will use this money to renovate their house, too.

loans.use: Ol hopes to use this loan to purchase more groceries to sell in large amounts.

loans.name: Upendo Group

texts.en: Martina M. is a single woman with two children, ages 4 and 7. She has a timber business. She wants to expand her business.

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To add to hardware business and expand it

loans.name: Seema's Group

texts.en:
I live in a brick mud house with my family in Multan, Pakistan. I have four kids: two girls and two boys. I am a textile designer and create embroidered clothes. My husband is a daily wage laborer. My eldest son now also works transporting goods on a donkey cart. My son would like to buy an additional donkey cart for his business. He feels that his income would double, and we would be able to repair our house.

This is a group loan, and the women in it have been together for more than one year. Waloo M.’s husband runs a small restaurant. Sajida B. and Jindo M. would use their loans to buy bull carts.

We all are mutually responsible for this loan; if one defaults, the others make up the difference.

loans.use: Buy a donkey cart

loans.name: Ghem

texts.en: Mrs. Ghem S., 22, is married with little children and works as a cleaner in HCC Company, earning around $1.50 a day. To supplement a good condition of living her husband Mr. Hy Moha, 29, works as a police officer watching a temple in Siem Reap province which in average gives him around $1 a day. With the loan he wants to renovate their house as now the construction has not been completed. This couple not only wants to use this loan to renovate their house, but they want to own a business by purchasing grocery items and reselling them for a profit. Finally, this couple would like to honestly thank all lenders who support them.

loans.use: Ghem would like to complete fixing her house and start a grocery business.

loans.name: Kahramon

texts.en: O. Kahramon lives in the J.Rasulov region. He is engaged in a home/family busines. Mr.O.  commercially sells  “sambusa” (it is the flour course with the meat that is baked in the coals according to the old recipes). His wife and the sisters are engaged in the business too. They make the special dough and filling but making the “sambusa” is his job. Now mr.O. requests the loan of 3800 STJ for an additional location.

loans.use: An additional location

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
I am the leader of a group of women in my neighborhood: Zahida B., Zakia B., Sharifan B., and Shahnaz B.. I have known all of them for many years, and we live in the city of Multan, famous in Pakistan for its pottery and temples.

I live in a one-room brick house with my four kids: two sons and two daughters. All my kids are under 15 and attend a local school, except the youngest who is not yet of school age. Becase I am divorced and my kids are small I am the only breadwinner in my family. To make a living I sell milk from my house. I need to increase my income and want to buy an additional cow. Zakia B., Zahida B., and Shahnaz B. would also buy cows. Sharifan B. sells pickles and wants to expand her business.

This is a group loan, and we all are mutually responsible for this loan.

loans.use: Buy a cow

loans.name: Sylivia

texts.en: Sylivia K. is a businesswoman running a wholesale shop in Nakifuma, with the help of her husband. She is 28 and has two children, plus one child of her sister's whom she cares for. She has been our client from day one, and it feels great growing with her. Her husband works in Jinja, another town, and it’s from here that he gets the goods for the shop, mainly on weekends when he comes back home in their family car. With her previous loan, she was able to add soda to her stock of flour, cooking oil, soap, matchboxes, and other items; with this loan, she wants to add beer. She believes nothing can stop her from success if she gets this loan.

loans.use: To buy beer for her wholesale shop

loans.name: Kilwoowa West C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Nusula N.. She is currently in the poultry business and is requesting a loan to buy more chicks. Nusula is 40 years old and is divorced. She has 4 children ranging from age 16 to 24 and her children go to school. Each week, Nusula makes approximately UGX 30000 in profit and with the extra profit from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children. Nusula has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 in order to buy more chicks and poultry feed and the loan was paid back on time.

Nusula is joined in her small group by Neter N., Aisha N., Regina N., and Sifuna N.. Neter N. has a business in farming and wants to expand the business. Aisha N. is currently operating a business in fish selling and wants a loan to add to the fish business. Regina N. operates a business of a retail shop and wants to purchase more shop items. Sifuna N. is currently in the business of charcoal selling and is requesting a loan to buy more sacks of charcoal.

loans.use: To expand poultry business and make more profit

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Zeby

texts.en: S. Zeby is 52 years old and she lives in the B.Gafurov region of Tajikistan. She is married and has 4 children. Mrs.S. has been an active client of  MicroInvest since 2002.  Mrs. S.'s background is as a school teacher. It is difficult to live on a  teacher's salary so she also sells clothing for children. She has the good assortment and she works with wholesale suppliers that permit her to buy the clothing at  prices that are lower than the bazaar prices. She has been in this  business for 17 years and has developed excellent business skills. Now Mrs. S. requests the loan of 2600 STJ to grow her business and to increase her inventory.

loans.use: To grow her business and increase her inventory.

loans.name: Molemo Group

texts.en: Anna K. is a married woman. She has three children, ages 21, 17 and 15. She has a timber business. She wants to expand her business.

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Kilwoowa West D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Halima N.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to buy a sewing machine. Halima is 35 years old and a widow. She has 2 children aged 16 and 20 and her children go to school. Each week, Halima makes approximately UGX 15000 in profit and with the extra profit from her loan she hopes to be able to buy more cloth material. Halima has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Halima is joined in her small group by Florence K., Zubeda M., Rehema N., and Rovisa N.. Florence K. has a business in charcoal sales and wants to add to her charcoal business. Zubeda M. is currently operating a retail shop business and wants a loan to increase capital stock. Rehema N. operates a business of charcoal selling and wants to boost business. Rovisa N. is currently in the business of selling clothes and is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To uplift tailoring business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Ouy

texts.en: Mrs. Ouy K., 77, is a widow and works on a plot of farmland growing a variety of vegetables and bearing fruits to sell at the market, making on average about $3.50 a day in profit. She has two children, one of whom is also a farmer and normally makes on average $2 each a day. Mrs. K. will use this loan to purchase a grocery stand in the market. She and her children would like to deeply thank all lenders who share their capital to make her business go forward.

loans.use: Ouy would like to use this loan to purchase a grocery stand in the market.

loans.name: Epimako

texts.en: Epimako M., a 65-year-old resident of Mayangayanga in the Kayunga district, is a businessman dealing in used clothes locally referred to as ‘mivumba,’ such as shirts, trousers, shorts, jackets and coats, for boys and men. He buys them every Monday from Kampala, the capital city, and sells them to his customers in the daily markets all around his neighborhood, using his motorcycle as transport. He is married with 15 children and also looks after three of his grandchildren. He has been our client for one-and-a-half years, and the loans have helped him with buying more clothes and increasing the volume of his sales, enabling him to pay school fees and save.

loans.use: Buy more shirts, trousers, shorts, jackets and coats to sell

loans.name: Nyenga West A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Margret S.. She is currently in the business of owning a drug store and is requesting a loan to purchase more drugs for sale. Margret is 40 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. She has 2 children aged 18 and 20 and her children go to school. Each week, Margret makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a commercial house. Margret has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 in order to buy more drugs and the loan was paid back on time.

Margret is joined in her small group by Milly N., Petwa K., Prossy B., and Sarah W.. Milly N. owns a retail shop and wants to stock more goods. Petwa K. is currently operating a business raising poultry and wants a loan to buy more chicks. Prossy B. operates a charcoal selling business and wants to buy more bags of charcoal. Sarah W. is currently owns a bakery and is requesting a loan to buy a bakery mixture machine.

loans.use: To add stock and increase sales to her drug store business

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Mrs. Hem S., 49, is married with five children and she stays at home cooking food for her family members. To supplement her standard of living she owns a plot of land growing a variety of vegetables and she makes on average $2 a day. To contribute to their living standard, her husband Mr. Sor Cheuon, 54, works as a teacher at high school in Prey Veng province making on average $3.33 a day. Two of their children work at a nearby factory at a salary of $80 each a month. Another three children are studying in Phnom Penh City. This couple hopes to use this loan to send their school-aged child to a university as they want their children to have better jobs in the future.

loans.use: Hem hopes to use this loan to send her school-aged child to a university as she and her husband want their children to have better jobs in the future.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty K. is 36 years old and married with three school-going children. She runs a retail shop together with her husband in Nakifuma, and she has been our client for over three years. The loans have really helped her in building her shop, especially with transporting her goods from the trading center, although at times she buys goods from the wholesale shop in her area that belongs to another member of ours.

loans.use: Restock her shop with more sugar, salt, soap, Vaseline and toothpaste

loans.name: Salomat

texts.en: Y. Salomat is 48 years old. She lives in the B.Gafurov region of Tajikistan and she is married and has 4 children. Mrs. Y. has been a client of MicroInvest since 2006. Her business and the stability of her income helped her to repay her  previous loans on time and to improve the loan terms. She sells bakery products;  (rolls, spice cakes, cakes and etc). She has a good assortment and works only with the vendors that permit her to sell  the freshest baked goods. Now Mrs. Y. requests the loan of 1600 STJ so she can increase the assortment of baked goods she sells.

loans.use: To increase baked good inventory

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Mrs. Long S., 45, works with her husband as brokers (purchasing cows and reselling them for a profit) making collectively on average around $14 a day of income. This couple has five children. One is employed by a garment factory, at a salary of $100 a month. The other four children are students. This couple hopes to use this loan to purchase more calves to breed and resell them for an additional profit.

loans.use: Long and her husband hope to use this loan to purchase more calves to breed and sell them up for an additional profit.

loans.name: Marifat

texts.en: M. Marifat is 48 years old. She lives in the B.Gafurov region and she is married and has 5 children. She dreams of a happy future for her children so she works hard to make that dream become a reality. Mrs. M. was previously engaged in selling food products but had  stiff competition so she decided to change the direction of her business and start a new business selling  house wares. She opened a small trade outlet where she sells her products. Now Mrs. M. requests the loan of 3100 STJ to replenish her inventory.

loans.use: To replenish her inventory

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 28 years old. He is married and has two children. One of them is going to school. His elderly mother and his two sisters are staying with him in his rented house. He has a small general store in his house. He applied to borrow $1200 to purchase new goods and home supplies to sell and improve his life by expanding his project. He wants to make new shelves and paint the store to increase his income and save for a better life for his family.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase new goods and home supplies

loans.name: Francis' Group

texts.en: In Nakifuma, a location dominated by farming, Francis, the chairperson of Mayangayanga Development Group has taken his own path. He is a businessman dealing in shoes for men, women and children. He buys the shoes from Kampala twice a week and sells them to locals in the daily markets around his home. He is 45 years old and married with six children, plus nine of his brothers’ children whom he cares for. He is our client and has always been prompt with his payments. His main aim is to buy more shoes and increase his income to enable him to complete paying school fees for his children.

loans.use: To buy more shoes of different sizes and types

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Mrs. Kong P., 27, works as a grocery vendor earning around $5 a day in profit. To supplement their living standard, her husband Mr. Sok Leang, 46, works as a pig raiser and also a farmer and he makes on average $2.50 a day. This couple hopes to use this loan to purchase fertilizer to put into their rice field to gain more yield.

loans.use: Kong hopes to use this loan to purchase fertilizer to put into her rice field to gain more yield.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To expand and boost poultry business

loans.name: Saom

texts.en: Mrs. Saom Y., 55, works as a farmer and purchases rice and resells it for profit, which everyday makes her on average $3 a day in profit. Mrs. Saom has seven children. Three of her children work in garment factories and one other works as a farmer. To improve their living condition, Mrs. Saom is requesting a loan from Kiva of about $500 to breed pigs and resell them when they grow up.

loans.use: Saom would like to breed pigs and sell them when they grow up.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Saom Yaom has fully repaid this Kiva loan early.

Thank you for your support of Cambodian entrepreneurs. Lenders like you allow entrepreneurs around the world access to low-interest loans to finance their small businesses and support their families.

We hope you will continue your support by reinvesting in another Kiva entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Upper Naava South A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Betty J.. She is currently in the business of selling new clothes and is requesting a loan to boost business. Betty is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is an electrician. She has 2 children aged 10 and 16 and her children go to school. Each week, Betty makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to invest in the business and also construct a commercial house Betty has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Betty is joined in her small group by Rose G., Jacenta L., Pegie K., and Joyce L.. Rose G. has a business selling matooke and wants to purchase more matooke for sale. Jacenta L. is currently operating a business selling charcoal and wants a loan to increase business. Pegie K. operates a tailoring business nd wants to buy a sewing machine. Joyce L. is currently in the business of operating a grocery store and is requesting a loan to expand business by adding stock.

loans.use: To expand clothing business and make more profits

loans.name: Adenike

texts.en: Adenike O., 47-years-old, is married with five children.  She hails from Mushin in Lagos State. Mrs. O. has been in business since 1985, selling kerosene, drinks and food products. She is requesting a loan of $450 to purchase additional inventory for her store.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene, drinks and food products for resale

loans.name: Malika

texts.en: K. Malika has been an active client of  MicroInvest since 2002. She has improved her business thanks her ability to get business development loans. The stability of her business helped her to repay her previous loans on time. Mrs. K. currently sells socks, boots, and tights. She is very polite so she has a lot of customers. Now mrs.K. requests the loan of 3100 STJ for 6 months to buy children's shoes to add to her current inventory . The loan would permit her to improve her existing inventory and to increase the income from her business.

loans.use: Increase her inventory of children's shoes

loans.name: Etibar

texts.en:
Etibar is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan. There, he has settled in the Fizuli region, in a Kayidish village. This village was built for IDPs.

Etibar has run this business for five years now. This man is married and also has two children. Now, he needs a loan of $725 to buy a cow.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Nyenga West C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Faridah S.. She is currently in the business of operating a hardware shop and is requesting a loan to buy more hardware materials. Faridah is 28 years old and is married with a husband that is a farmer. She has 1 child aged 4 who does not go to school. Each week, Faridah makes approximately UGX 28600 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to set up a nursery school. Faridah has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to buy more goods for the shop and the loan was paid back on time.

Faridah is joined in her small group by Oliver K., Florence K., Musa S., and Kizza N.. Oliver K. has a beauty salon business and wants to buy more salon equipment. Flornece K. is currently operating a poultry farm and wants a loan to buy local chickens. Musa S. also operates a poultry farm and wants to buy more chicks and chicken feed. Kizza N. is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to buy more materials.

loans.use: To boost hardware business by increasing stock.

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin A., 45-years-old, is married with five children. She hails from Lagos State. Mrs. A. has been selling cosmetics since 1998.  She is requesting a loan of $450 to purchase more cosmetics for her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory of cosmetics for resale

loans.name: Nyenga West D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Juliet O.. She is currently in the business of charcoal selling and is requesting a loan to buy more sacks for charcoal. Juliet is 48 years old and is married. She has 2 children aged 25 and 28 and both of them are primary school teachers. Each week, Juliet makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to set up a salon. Juliet has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to buy more sacks of charcoal and the loan was paid back on time.

Juliet is joined in her small group by Nusiata N., Margret I., Shilah N., and Hawa Kogoya. Nusiata N. has a operates a hotel and wants to buy more furniture and utensils. Margret I. is currently operating a business in poultry farming and wants a loan to buy more chicks and poultry feeds. Shilah N. owns a retail shop and wants to buy more products. Hawa Kogoya is currently in the business of brick laying and is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand charcoal selling business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth A., 37-years-old, is married with two children. She hails from Lagos State. Mrs.  A. has been in the business of selling drinks since 1990. She is also a fashion designer. Her request for a loan of $450 will give her the funds to purchase a higher inventory of drinks for resale.

loans.use: To purchase a larger inventory of  drinks for resale

loans.name: Houl

texts.en: Mrs. Houl M., 40, works as an egg seller making on average around $3 a day. She has three children. One of her children works as a garment worker and two others work as a blacksmith making on average $2 each a day of profit. Mrs. Houl hopes to use this loan to purchase a small stand in front of the market and purchase more eggs to sell in large amounts.

loans.use: Houl hopes to use this loan to purchase a small stand in front of the market and purchase more eggs to sell in large amounts.

loans.name: Moranun

texts.en: Moranun Z. is 32-years old, married with three children. She lives in Mushin in  Lagos State of Nigeria. Since 2006 Mrs. Z.  has been selling recharge cards, VCD's & DVD's cassette. she is requesting for a loan of $450 to enable her buy more recharge cards as well as VCD's & DVD's cassette for sale. She equally rent out DVD and VCD cassetteto people living in her community. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more recharge cards, DVD's and VCD's cassette for sale.

loans.name: Nyenga East A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jesca T.. She is currently in the business of operating a retail shop and is requesting a loan to increase her stock of products. Jesca is 45 years old and is married. Her husband is a primary school teacher. She has 2 children aged 22 and 20 and her children go to school. Each week, Jesca makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a commercial house. Jesca has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to buy more products and the loan was paid back on time.

Jesca is joined in her small group by Alice K., Agatha N., Luga N., and Allen N.. Alice K. has a hotel business and wants to buy more foodstuffs and furniture. Agatha N. is currently operating a hotel business and wants a loan to purchase a fridge. Luga N. operates a poultry farm and wants to purchase more poultry feeds. Allen N. is currently operates a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to buy a hair steamer and dryer.

loans.use: To purchase more shop items

loans.name: Munira

texts.en:
N. Munira is 36 years old. She is alone raising two children.

Munira sells clothing for men. She rents her trading place in one of the stores of the city. Being in this business already for 8 years, Munira obtained rich experience in choosing the goods of a good quality and at acceptable prices for her clientele. She tries to have a wide range of goods. Considering that the current business is the main source of income for the family Munira is doing her best to make it stable and successful.

Munira has been provided with several loans by IMON. All the previous loans were managed accurately and in a timely manner. Now Munira requests 600.00 US dollars for the term of 6 months. She is planning to purchase new clothing for men for selling in order to increase the range of goods. Munira thanks all for support and promises to pay the loan on time.

loans.use: Purchasing new clothing for men for selling.

loans.name: Nisolat

texts.en:
N. Nisolat is 48 years old. She and her husband, a driver, have raised 2 children.

For more than 8 years Nisolat has been selling clothing for kids. Nisolat delivers all the goods from the neighboring city. The prices for Nisolat's clothing are attractive for the population with the average level of income. Nisolat has built up her clientele over the years and the business has become stable generating income for the family.

Now Nisolat plans to purchase new clothing for kids for the spring season. For this purpose she requests 600.00 Somoni (175.00 US dollars) for the term of 3 months. Nisolat has already had an IMON loan and has demonstrated herself as a reliable honest client. Nisolat promises to pay the loan on time and thanks all for support.

loans.use: Purchase new kids clothing for selling.

loans.name: Oimniso

texts.en:
S. Oimniso is 44 years old. She is married with three children.

Oimniso is running her business for about 20 years. She sells clothing for women like knitted jackets, overcoats, leather topcoats and others in one of the stores of the city. Oimniso is working hard in order to make her business successful, so that it generates the significant income allowing the family to improve the living conditions.

Being polite by her nature Oimniso is doing her best to have the wide range of goods that satisfies the needs of clients with various tastes and incomes. And now Oimniso is planning to purchase new clothing for women in order to enlarge her range of goods.

For this purpose she requests 600.00 US dollars for the term of 6 months. Oimniso has already proved herself as a reliable and honest client in cooperation with IMON. Oimniso promises to pay the loan on time and thanks all for support.

loans.use: Purchase of new clothing for women.

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Mrs. Long N., 39, is a vendor of Khmer natural medicines and she makes on average around $2 a day of profit. To sustain the standard of living her husband Mr. Vanty, 40, works as a motor-taxi driver everyday and he earns on average about $2 a day. This couple has six children, two of whom are working as garment workers and who receive a salary of $80 each month total. Their other four children are students. They are now currently requesting a loan from Kiva of about $700 to purchase a motor-bike for their daughters' commute.

loans.use: Long would like to use her loan to purchase a motor-bike for her daughters' commute.

loans.name: Fasat

texts.en: Fasat Akirinade, 29-years-old  has one child. She is from the Lagos State, Nigeria. She has been in the business of selling building materials since 2003. She is requesting a loan amount of $450 to purchase additional building materials for resale.

loans.use: To purchase additional building materials for resale

loans.name: Nyenga East B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Teopista N.. She is currently operating a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to buy more hair dryers. Teopista is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. She has 6 children ranging from age 6 to 18 and her children go to school. Each week, Teopista makes approximately UGX 32000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her salon business Teopista has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 1300000 in order to buy two hair dryers and the loan was paid back on time.

Teopista is joined in her small group by Lovis K., Rose N., Betty N., and Annet N.. Lovis K. operates a hardware shop and wants to buy more hardware materials. Rose N. is currently operating a farm and wants a loan to expand her business. Betty N. operates a bar and wants to buy more beers and drinks. Annet N. is currently owns a restaurant and is requesting a loan to buy more foodstuffs, soft drinks and utensils.

loans.use: To buy more beauty salon equipment and increase business

loans.name: Jumoke

texts.en: Jumoke A., 57-years-old, has six children. Her family lives in the Oshodin area of Lagos State, Nigeria. Since 1992 she has been selling building materials. Mrs. A. is requesting a loan amount of $450 to purchase additional inventory for resale.

loans.use: To purchase building materials inventory for resale

loans.name: Rustam

texts.en:
S. Rustam is 21 years old. He is not married. He is living with his parents and supporting them and he has already become the main bread-winner.

Rustam sells sporting accessories like training suits and sneakers, training equipment, footballs, tennis balls and others. The business is stable and generates the main income for the family. Now Rustam is planning to enlarge the range of goods he sells. For this purpose he requests 1000.00 US dollars for the term of 6 months.

This is the second loan of Rustam and the previous one was managed with accuracy. Rustam thanks everyone supporting him and promises to pay the loan on time.

loans.use: Purchase of sporting accessories for increasing the range of goods.

loans.name: Nyenga East C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Josephine Ssenabulya. She is currently operates a drug store and is requesting a loan to purchase more drugs for sale. Josephine is 35 years old and is married. Her husband is a pastor. She has 4 children ranging from age 10 to 20 and her children go to school. Each week, Josephine makes approximately UGX 35000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to start a piggery business. Josephine has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to buy two hair dryers and the loan was paid back on time.

Josephine is joined in her small group by Rose B., Jane B., Ruth N., and Erina N.. Rose B. has a farming business and wants to modernize her farming system. Jane B. is currently selling charcoal and wants a loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. Ruth N. operates a business of fish selling and wants to purchase more fish nets. Erina N. is currently operates a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to buy more salon equipment.

loans.use: To add capital to a  drug store and improve it.

loans.name: Sokheang

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokheang was married in 2000 and has two daughters who are studying in a village school. She has been weaving and raising pigs at home for 8 years. For nearly 15 years, her husband has been selling baby pigs. He usually drives a motorbike to travel from place to place to buy and sell pigs.

Sokheang is requesting a loan for $1000 from MAXIMA to purchase more pigs to resell. This is the fourth loan that Sokheang has requested. Sokheang and her husband hope that this business will be able to support the family and provide enough income so their two daughters can continue their studying and attend high school in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs to resell

loans.name: Khim

texts.en: Mrs. Khim Poin, 40, works as a farmer making on average $1 a day. To supplement the living standard her husband Mr. Yem Yan, 46, works as a carpenter making on average $1 a day. This couple has four children and all of them work as a garment workers earning around $80 each a month. They hope to use this loan to purchase a plot of farmland to produce more.

loans.use: Khim hopes to use this loan to purchase a plot of farmland to produce more.

loans.name: Marifat

texts.en:
Z. Marifat is 42 years old. She is married with 4 children.

Marifat sells clothing and shoes for kids. Her trading place is located in the central market of the city. Once a week Marifat travels to the neighboring city to purchase new goods for selling. Marifat’s goods meet the requirements of her clients and attract customers having an average level of income. The business of Marifat is stable and brings considerable income to the family budget.

Today Marifat requests 700.00 Somoni (225.00 US dollars) for the term of 3 months. She plans to purchase new clothing and shoes for kids for the spring season for selling. Marifat was provided with loans by IMON and has proved herself as a reliable client. She thanks all for support and promises to be precise in the loan payment.

loans.use: Purchase of new clothing and shoes for kids for selling.

loans.name: Abdurauf

texts.en:
A. Abdurauf is 29 years old. He is married with three kids.

Abdurauf provides transportation services for passengers. Initially he started as a driver. Over time he saved sufficient funds and purchased a minivan that he has used until now for providing services. Having the stable business Abdurauf is working hard in order to support his family and make savings.

Abdurauf needs to purchase spare parts for his minivan. At the same time Abdurauf needs some additional funds for purchasing one more minivan. In order to achieve all this Abdurauf requests 800.00 US dollars for the term of 12 months. A previous loan by Abdurauf was paid back in a timely manner, and now he promises to manage the loan with accuracy and thanks all for support.

loans.use: Purchase of spare parts for repair and also purchasing of one more minivan.

loans.name: Nyenga Esat D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Josephine Nakanaabi. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to buy more cloth materials. Josephine is 40 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has 1 child aged 20 who does not go to school. Each week, Josephine makes approximately UGX 32000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to set up a bigger boutique. Josephine has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Josephine is joined in her small group by Rose K., Edith Kizza, Daral N., and Sylvia A.. Rose K. operates a retail shop and wants to increase her stock. Edith Kizza is currently operating a business in farming and wants a loan to buy modern farm equipment. Daral N. operates a beauty salon and wants to buy a hair dryer and steamer. Sylvia A. is in the hotel buisness and is requesting a loan to buy more foodstuffs and soft drinks.

loans.use: To expand tailoring business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Inom

texts.en:
Inom Y. is 45 years old and he is married with three children. Inom sells CDs and DVDs, as well as eggs, in the central local market, and he has been in this line of business for 10 years. Over the years, his eldest son (pictured) became more involved in the business and now helps his father at the market. Inon's business generates sufficient income to support his large family. 

Inom already received one loan from IMON and he successfully repaid that loan without any problems whatsoever. Now, he seeks $1,000 to purchase a computer in order to record DVDs and CDs and to purchase additional eggs, and he is confident that he can repay this loan on time. Inom would like to thank everyone for their support.

loans.use: To purchase a computer to record DVDs and CDs.

loans.name: Nyenga East E Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Suzan N.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and selling clothes and is requesting a loan to increase her stock of clothes. Suzan is 40 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has 2 children raged 24 and 26. Each week, Suzan makes approximately UGX 28000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand business Suzan has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to increase stock and the loan was paid back on time.

Suzan is joined in her small group by Suzan B., Faisi N., Eseza N., and Fardia M.. Suzan B. has a farming business and wants to buy more land for cultivation. Faisi N. is currently operating a business in poultry farming and wants a loan to buy more chicks and poultry feeds. Eseza N. operates a farm and wants to enlarge her farm. Fardia M. is currently in the business of cattle rearing and is requesting a loan to buy another cow.

loans.use: To improve clothing business

loans.name: Farruh

texts.en:
Farruh N. is 23 years old. He runs a small shop where he produces small carts, which are used by his customers to transport food and other goods they purchase at the market to their homes. In general, the families in Tajikistan are large and, in preparation for family celebrations, individual family members purchase all of the necessary goods at the market for such celebrations. Thus, Farruh produces small hand carts and leases them to customers so they can transport their purchased goods to their vehicles or to the public transportation stops. 

Farruh is seeking a loan of $600 to purchase additional raw materials (e.g., wheels) required to make the carts. This would be Farruh's first loan and he is confident that he can repay it on time.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials in order to produce new carts

loans.name: Mok Sophoin's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. M. Sophoin (pictured on the left) was selected to be a group leader for a loan from Maxima. The group includes four families, who live on an island in the Mekong River.

1-Mrs. M. Sophoin (age 40) and her husband have been married since 1990. Her husband is a fisherman. They have four children—one son and three daughters. Two of Sophoin’s daughters weave silk at home and the other two children attend the local school. Sophoin has had a silk weaving business for eight years. She is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA for the amount of $50. She plans to use this money to purchase silk materials for weaving.

2- Mrs. R. Dalin (age 25) and her husband have been married since 2003. They have two young children—one son and one daughter. She has had a silk weaving business for thirteen years. Her husband is a worker. She is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA for $50. She plans to use this money to purchase silk materials for weaving.

3- Mr. C. Sam Aun (age 27) and his wife have been married in 2002.They have two young daughters. They are in the business of weaving silk for thirteen years. Sam Aun has borrowed money from MAXIMA for the first time with the amount of $50. He will use this money to purchase silk materials for weaving.

4- Mrs. K. Hut is forty-one years old (pictured with her daughter on the right). She has six children—three sons and three daughters. She has been a silk weaver for five years. Her husband is a fisherman. She is requesting money from MAXIMA for the first time for $50. She plans to use this money to purchase silk materials for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loans.name: Rashidat

texts.en: Rashidat O. is 29-years-old, married with six children. She hails from Mushin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells building materials. Mrs. O. is requesting a loan amount of $450 to purchase additional inventory for resale.

loans.use: To purchase building materials for  resale

loans.name: Sun Ang's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Ang (pictured on the left) was selected to be a group leader for a loan from Maxima. The group includes two families who live across the Mekong River about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

1-Mrs. S. Ang, 41, and her husband have been married since 1986.They have three children—one son and two daughters. Ang sells grilled sweet potatoes in the village. Her husband is a fisherman and also grows rice. She is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA for $150. She plans to use this money to help her husband's rice growing farm.

2- Mr. P. Chandara, 36, and his wife have been married since 1991 and have two sons. He runs a motor taxi business and his wife stays at home to take care of their children. He is requesting his first loan from MAXIMA for $150. He plans to use this money to repair his house.

loans.use: For growing rice and repairing house

loans.name: Nkokonjeru East A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Harriet N.. She is currently in the business of selling matooke and is requesting a loan to boost business. Harriet is 38 years old and is divorced. She has 5 children ranging from age 6 to 18 and her children go to school. Each week, Harriet makes approximately UGX 49000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to take care of her home and ensure a healthy family Harriet has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to start her matooke business and the loan was paid back on time.

Harriet is joined in her small group by Nuulu Nakyanzi, Sarah N., Hadija M., and Teopista K.. Nuulu Nakyanzi has a business in poultry farming and wants to buy poultry feeds. Sarah N. is currently operates a hardware shop and wants a loan to increase stock in her shop. Hadija M. operates a business of poultry farming and wants to buy poultry feeds. Teopista K. is currently in the business of charcoal selling and is requesting a loan to construct a business stall.

loans.use: To purchase more matooke for sale to villages

loans.name: Chamroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Neom Chamroeun and her family live on the Koh Dach Island in the Mekong River. She and her husband have been married since 1989, and they have two sons and two daughters. Three of the children study at the local school, and one is still young and stays at home.

Mrs. Chamroeun runs a grocery store in front of her house. Her husband, Sam An, is a farmer. He grows vegetables and fruit, such as tomatoes and papayas, which he sells in Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Chamroeun is requesting a second loan for $500 from MAXIMA. She will use this money to purchase grocery items for reselling.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for reselling

loans.name: Kubirat

texts.en: Kubirat Olarewaju, 42-years-old, is married with four children. Her family lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She has been selling building materials for 15 years. Mrs. O. is requesting a loan amount of $450 to purchase additional inventory for resale.

loans.use: To purchase building materials for resale

loans.name: Khano's Group

texts.en:
I am Khano M. and I live in Multan, a city famous in Pakistan for its shrines. I live in a one-room mud house with my husband and six kids: four boys and two girls. My husband sells bricks, and I raise cows at home to make a living. I would use the loan to increase the number of my cows in my herd.

I have four other women in my loan group. All of them are my neighbors, and we always help each other in times of need. We have also learnt to be punctual and responsible after becoming a part of this loan group. Kumo M. embroiders clothes and also raises cows; she also wants to buy a cow. Sajida M. has a small farm and would like to buy a cow. Amna M. and Ameer M. both would also buy cows.

loans.use: Buy a cow

loans.name: Kudirat

texts.en: Kudirat O., 40-years-old, is married with three children. Her family lives in the Mushin area of Lagos State, Nigeria. Since 1992, She has been selling building hardware. Her request for a loan of $450 is to purchase additional building hardware for resale.

loans.use: To purchase additional building hardware for resale

loans.name: Buziika South A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Esther Z.. She is currently operates a retail shop and is requesting a loan to increase her working capital. Esther is 35 years old and is married. She has 4 children ranging from age 6 to 13 and her children go to school. Each week, Esther makes approximately UGX 31500 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to re-invest in her business and cater to her family's needs. Esther has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 800000 in order to purchase more shop items and the loan was paid back on time.

Esther is joined in her small group by Mariam P., Regina N., Madina N., and Lukia N.. Mariam P. has a business selling clothes and wants to increase working capital. Regina N. is currently operates a clothing business and wants a loan to purchase a variety of clothes for sale. Madina N. operates a business of selling snacks and wants to buy a microwave machine for warming snacks. Lukia N. is currently operates a retail shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more shop items.

loans.use: To boost retail shop business

loans.name: Vannak

texts.en:
Mrs. A. Vannak has been married since1990 and has four children, one son and three daughters who study at a local school. She has been selling Khmer noodles for 2 years.

Her husband has been a fishermA. for 10 years. Now he wants to start a new business of a running horse cart. They hope that their business will support the family and provide funds so their children cA. study at as high a level as possible.

Mrs. Vannak is requesting a loA. for $300 from MAXIMA for the fourth time to purchase a horse for her husband's running horse cart.

loans.use: To purchase horse for running horse cart

loans.name: Kaneez's Group

texts.en:
I am Kaneez M., wife of Sher Aman. I am the leader of a group of four women--Pathani M., Khursheed B.. Baksh E., and Begum M.. These women are my neighbors, and I want to help them overcome poverty and give their families a better future.

I live in Multan, a medium-sized city in Pakistan, with my husband and four kids: two boys and two girls. All my kids are under 16. My husband is a farmer, and I raise cows. I would use the loan to buy an additional cow for my business.

As for my group members, Pathani M.’s husband is a public transport driver, and she sells milk. Khursheed B. does embroidery and would use the loan to buy her husband a donkey cart. Baksh E. would use the loan for her son’s grocery store. Begum M. will also buy a cow with her share of loan.

loans.use: Buy a cow

loans.name: Rukayat

texts.en: Rukayat G. is married with a child. She is 25-years-old and lives in Oshodin, in Lagos State. She has been in the business of selling plywood since 2003. She is requesting a loan of $450 to purchase additional inventory for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more plywood for resale

loans.name: Shamshad's Group

texts.en:
I am 27-year-old married woman with three girls, aged 4, 2, and six months. As they are small they do not attend school currently, but will surely go to school in future. I run a boutique from my house, and my husband transports goods on a bull cart. My boutique does well, and with the profits I bought a television for my house. I would use this loan to expand my boutique and produce a greater variety of embroidered clothes. This is a group loan. Shahnaz B. would use the loan to expland her husband's vegetable business. Faizan M. wants to buy a cow. Mukhtar B. sells milk from her house. Haseena B.’s husband sells vegetables in the city vegetable market.

All of us have been friends for a long time and work hard to earn a decent livelihood for our families.

loans.use: Expand boutique

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam A. is 40-years-old, married with two children and lives in Itire in Lagos State, Nigeria. Since 1993. she has been in the business of selling plywood. Her loan request of $450 is to purchase additional inventory  for resale.

loans.use: To purchase additional plywood for resale

loans.name: Bisi

texts.en: Bisi D. is married with one child. She is 22-years-old and lives in the Mushin area of Lagos State. She sells plywood and is requesting a loan amount of $450 to acquire additional inventory for resale.

loans.use: To purchase additional plywood for resale

loans.name: Buziika South B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jane S.. She is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan to purchase a babelock and clothe designing machines. Jane is 31 years old and is a widow. She has 2 children ranging from age 4 to 6 and her children go to school. Each week, Jane makes approximately UGX 42000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to take children to school and meet the family's basic needs Jane has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to purchase her own sewing machine and the loan was paid back on time.

Jane is joined in her small group by Esther K., Hasifa N., Jane M., and Olivia N.. Esther K. has a business in cattle rearing and wants to purchase a cow. Hasifa N. is currently operating a business in charcoal sales and wants a loan to increase working capital. Jane M. operates a business of charcoal selling and wants to increase working capital. Olivia N. is currently owns a retail shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more products and increase her customer base.

loans.use: To add machinery to her tailoring business and increase business

loans.name: Buzika South C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Jennifer N.. She is currently in the business of pig rearing and is requesting a loan to buy a cow and start rearing cattle. Jennifer is 45 years old and is married . She has 3 children ranging from age 19 to 23 and her children go to school. Each week, Jennifer makes approximately UGX 42000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to send her last born to university. Jennifer has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 in order to construct a pig house and that loan was paid back on time.

Jennijfer is joined in her small group by Sylvia N., Judith N., Fatuma N., and Betty N.. Sylvia N. business is selling charcoal and wants to construct a charcoal store. Judith N. is currently operating a business selling raw food and wants a loan to add capital and start purchasing in bulk. Fatuma N. operates a business of rearing pigs and wants to buy more pigs and pig feeds. Betty N. is currently in the business of selling raw food and is requesting a loan to increase working capital.

loans.use: To start a cattle rearing business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Vahida

texts.en:
Vahida is a 50-year-old woman who lives in a village called Šišići near the town of Živinice. She is married and her husband is retired and has a very small monthly pension. This is her second loan through MCO WWI, this time in the amount of US$ 1,125.

Vahida and her son have opened a coffee bar and they want to use this loan to renovate it. In this way she will ensure a workplace and a regular income source for her son and their household.

loans.use: Renovation of their coffee bar

loans.name: Marian

texts.en: Marian S. is 33-years-old, married with three children. She lives in Mushin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is in the business fo selling office supplies and is requesting a loan amount of $450 to purchase additional inventory for resale.

loans.use: To purchase additional office supplies for resale

loans.name: Mkwawa D Group

texts.en:
Kikwisa M., age 26, is married and has 2 children (ages 7 and 4). She has a business selling clothing and cosmetics which she started 2 years ago. Kikwisa's business is open from 8 am to noon and from 4 pm to 6 pm daily, and she is able to make a monthly profit of about US$52.

In the past, Kikwisa has taken out a previous loan with Tujijenge to expand her business. She now hopes to receive a new loan to purchase an additional stock of clothing and cosmetics. She will share this loan with her sub-group members who have businesses clothing, charcoal, and food sales.

In the picture, Kikwisa is the one on the far left.

loans.use: Purchase of a stock of clothing and cosmetics

loans.name: Malohat

texts.ru:
Malohat G. is 48 years old, she has 6 children -- 3 sons and 3 daughters. Her oldest son and his father are in Russia to make money, her second son serves in the military, her third son helps take care of his mother and helps feed the animals. All Malohat's daughters already have their own families. She has 5 grandchildren. Malohat has a university diploma and she used to work as a school teacher.

Now, because of her illness, Malohat does not work, she spends all her time at home and enjoys very much taking care of her animals. Currently, she has 3 cows and 10 sheep. Since now animals are cheap on the market, Malohat would like to increase the quantity of animals. This is why she decided to approach MicroInvest for a loan.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva volunteer.

Гуфранова Малохат,возрост 48 лет имеет 6 детей трое сыновей и трое дeвочек. Старший сын с отцом уехали на заработки а Россию , второй сын служит в Армии, третиий сын помогает маме по уходу и откорму скота. Все девочки уже имеют свои семьи. Малохат уже имеет 5 внуков. Она имеет высшее образавоние, раньше работала учительницей в средней школе.

А сейчас по болезни вышла на пенсию, и все свое время проводит дома и очень любит ухаживать за скотом. Сейчас имеет 3 коровы и 10 баранов. И пока скот дешевый на базарах она хочет увеличить домашний скот. Поэтому решила обратится в Микроинвест.

loans.use: To purchase more animals

loans.name: Zabidahon

texts.ru:
Zabidahon M. lives in the city of Qurgan-Tube. She is 29 years old, single and does not have children. She has a university degree in education. Zabidahon works in school №1 of Quargan-Tube. Additionally, she has a business. She sews dresses and sells them to clients. She would like to use her loan to purchase material in order to sew dresses and sell them to clients. She plans to repay her loan within 6 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva volunteer.

Мамаджанова Забидахон Рахманджановна жительница города Курган-тюбе.Возраст 29 лет , не замужем, детей не имеет. Образование высшее, по специальности преподаватель средней школы. Работает в лицее №1 г. Курган-тюбе. Кроме того работает в сфере производства. Занимается пошивом платьев. Планирует получить кредит для приобретения материала, чтобы отшивать платья и продавать клиентам. Кредит планирует погасить в течении 6 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase material for dresses

loans.name: Mtaji Wa Maskini C Group

texts.en:
Rehema N., age 38, is married and has 4 children (ages 18, 16, 15, and 12). She has a poultry business which she started 4 years ago. Her business is open from 9 am to 5 pm daily, and Rehema is able to make a monthly profit of around US$43.3.

In the past, Rehema has taken out one previous loan with Tujijenge Tanzania which she used to buy suit materials for sale, and to expand her poultry business. She now hopes to receive a new loan for further business expansion. She will share this loan with her sub-group members who have businesses in food, clothing, and livestock sales.

In the picture, Rehema is the first on the right.

loans.use: Purchase of poultry for sale

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin A. is married with two children. She is 40-years-old and lives in Mushin in Lagos State, Nigeria.  She has been in business since 1993 selling beverages and other food products. Mrs. A. is also a fashion designer. Her request for a loan in the amount of $450 will be used to purchase more inventory for her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional beverages and food products for resale

loans.name: Usuf

texts.ru:
Usuf D. is 44 years old, he is married and has 8 children. He has a high school diploma and his profession is accounting. Currently, Usuf has an agricultural business; he grows potatoes. He has 15 years of experience in this business. Usuf plans to use his loan to purchase seed potatoes. He plans to repay the loan within 12 months. His business helps provide agricultural products to the community.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva volunteer.

Давлатов Юсуф Раджабович.Возраст44 года, женат имеет 8 детей.Образование среднее по специальности бухгалтер. Занимается сельским хозяйством по посадке картофеля.Опыт работы в данной деятельности 15 лет. Планирует получить кредит для того чтобы закупить семена картофеля. Погасить кредит планирует в течении 12 месяцев.Его бизнес позволяет обеспечить население сельхоз -продукцией.

loans.use: To purchase seed potatoes

loans.name: Belmiro Manuel

texts.pt:
Belmiro is a laborer and lives in the town of Morrumbene. Belmiro is not officially married, but he lives with a woman with whom he has 4 children. His girlfriend is not employed, but she takes care of the house and cares for the children and Belmiro. He works for a private company and his salary is approximately $90. For this reason he resolved to enter into the program so he could increase his monthly budget. His oldest children are in school. He took the loan to refurbish his home which is very old. He wants to purchase cement, squares, and zinc plates.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Belmiro e trabalhador e vive na vila de Morrumbene. Belmiro nao casou oficialmente mas vive com uma mulher com quem tem 4 filhos. A mulher de Belmiro nao esta empregada. apenas toma conta da casa e cuida dos filhos e do marido. Belmiro trabalha numa empresa privada e o seu salario e de aproximadamente $90. E por isso que ele resolveu entrar para o programa para poder reforcar o seu orcamento mensal. Os filhos mais velhos de Belmiro estao a estudar. Assim ele tomou o emprestimo para reabilitar a sua residencia que esta muito velha. Ele quer comprar cimento, e esquadria, chapas de zinco

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to refurbish home

loans.name: Folake

texts.en: Folake Oyeleke is 35-years-old, married with two children and lives in Mushin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She grinds dried yam (elubo), plantain and cassava into flour. Mrs. O. has been in business since 2003 and requests a loan amount of $450 to purchase a grinding machine which will increase her flour production.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding machine

loans.name: Funmilayo

texts.en: Funmilayo S. is 55-years-old, married and has three children. Her family lives in Mushin  Lagos State, Nigeria. She has been in business since 1987 selling elubo (dried yam, cassava and plantain). Mrs. S. is requesting a loan amount of $450 to purchase additional product for resale.

loans.use: To purchase elubo (dried yam, cassava and plantain) for resale

loans.name: Joaquina Rafael

texts.pt:
Joaquina is not officially married, but she lives with a man with whom she has 6 children. Her "husband" is a laborer for a private company. His salary is approximately $125. For this reason Joaquina, not being employed, is unable to support him with the expenses of their household. This loan that she is seeking is her first, and she wants to increase her stock including 2 sacks of rice, 1 sack of sugar, 20 litres of cooking oil, 1 sack of peanuts, 1 box of soap...etc. All of Joaquina's children are in school.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Joaquina nao casou oficialmente mas vive com um homem com quem tem 6 filhos. O marido de Joaquina e trabalhador numa empresa privada. o seu salario e de aproximadament de $125. Por isso Joaquina pelo facto de nao estar empregada para poder apoiar o marido nas despesas da casa. Este emprestimo que ela vai tomar e o primeiro, e ela quer aumentar o seu stock, a saber 2 sacos de arroz, 1 saco de acucar, 20 litros de oleo, 1 saco de amendoim 1 caixa de sabao etc. Todos os filhos da Joaquina estao a estudar.

loans.use: Purchase products to refill her small stand namely rice, salt, peanuts, sugar, oil, soap, and flour

loans.name: Buzika South D Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Josephine K.. She is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Josephine is 28 years old and is married. Her husband is an electrician. She has 2 children aged 1 and 3 and her children do not go to school. Each week, Josephine makes approximately UGX 35000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build her mother a house. Josephine has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 in order to invest in her charcoal business and the loan was paid back on time.

Josephine is joined in her small group by Getrude K., Sylvia K., Julian N., and Sarah K.. Getrude K. has a business selling clothes and wants to improve her business. Sylvia K. is currently operating a business selling charcoal and wants a loan to add more working capital. Julian N. operates a retail shop and wants to increase her stock. Sarah K. currently owns a retail shop and is requesting a loan to purchase a fridge.

loans.use: To expand her charcoal business

loans.name: Gulmurod

texts.ru:
Gulmurod A. lives in the city of Yavan. He is 43 years old, is married and has 6 children. He has a highschool diploma. Gulmurod has an animal rearing business. He would like to receive a loan in order to purchase young calves, which he will then feed and then resell. This is the only source of income for Gulmurod's family. Additionally, support of private animal rearing businesses gives an opportunity to develop the whole economic sector, which helps to keep meat prices stable. The client plans to repay his loan within 3 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva volunteer.

Абдиназаров Гулмурод Боведипович житель города Яван. 43 года, женат, имеет 6 детей. Образование среднее. Занимается животноводством. Кредит запрашивает для того, чтобы купить бычков для откормки и последующей их реализации.Этот вид бизнеса является единственным источником дохода его семьи. Так же развитие животноводства в частном порядке дает возможность развитию всего сектора, что позволяет сохранять цены на мясо. Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 3 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase calves

loans.name: Abegbo

texts.en: Abegho S. is 56-years-old, married and has six children. Her family lives in Mushin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She been selling yams, cassavas and plantains since 2003. She is requesting a loan amount of $450 to purchase additional inventory for resale.

loans.use: To purchase Elubo (dried yam ) for resale

loans.name: Naava East A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Ruth E.. She is currently in the business of raising and selling poultry and is requesting a loan to purchase poultry feed. Ruth is 30 years old and married. Her husband has a carpentry workshop. She has 3 children ranging from age 9 to 15 and her children go to school. Each week, Ruth makes approximately UGX 25000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business. Ruth has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to invest in a charcoal business and the loan was paid back on time.

Ruth is joined in her small group by Lydia C., Betty C., Fatuma L., and Sarah A.. Lydia C. has a business in vegetable selling and wants to add to the business. Betty C. is currently operating a business selling fish and wants a loan to add capital. Fatuma L. operates a business selling fish and wants to expand her business. Sarah A. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase more sacks of charcoal.

loans.use: To expand poultry business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Preciosa

texts.pt:
Preciosa wants to use this money to purchase firewood for the production of bricks. Preciosa is married and the mother of 4 children. Her husband works as a clerk in a government institution. His salary is approximately $150. Preciosa, besides making bricks for sale also raises chickens. Her 4 children are all in school.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Preciosa quer usar o dinheiro para a compra de lenha para o fabrico de tijolos. Preciosa e casada e mae de 4 filhos. O marido de Preciosa trabalha num Instituicao do governamental e escriturario. o seu salario e de aproximadamente $150. Preciosa, para alem do fabrico de tijolos para a venda ela tambem cria galinhas poedeiras. Os 4 filhos de Preciosa estao a estudar.

loans.use: Purchase firewood to produce bricks

loans.name: Urozaly

texts.ru:
Urozaly I. lives in the city of Yavan. He is 52 years old, is married and has 8 children. He has a high school diploma. Urozaly has an animal rearing business. He would like to receive a loan in order to purchase young calves, which he will then feed and then resell. This is the only way to obtain income for Urozaly's family. Additionally, support of private animal rearing businesses gives an opportunity to develop the whole economic sector, which helps to keep meat prices stable. The client plans to repay his loan within 3 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva volunteer.

Имомназаров Урозали Арзикулович житель города Яван. 52 года ,женат ,имеет 8 детей. Образование среднее. Занимается животноводством. Кредит запрашивает для того.чтобы купить бычков для откормки и последующей их реализации.Этот вид бизнеса является единственным источником дохода его семьи.Так же развитие животноводства в частном порядке дает возможность развитию всего сектора, что позволяет сохранять цены на мясо.Погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 3 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of young calves

loans.name: Namwezi East A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Unithy N.. She is currently in the business of fish selling and is requesting a loan to expand fish business. Unithy is 32 years old and is married. Her husband has a butcher's shop. She has five children ranging from age 3 to 16 and her children go to school. Each week, Unithy makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children. Unithy has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to buy chicken feed and drink and the loan was paid back on time.

Unithy is joined in her small group by Rehema N., Aisha Z., Nora N., and Joyce N.. Rehema N. has a business in poultry and wants to add to the business. Aisha Z. is currently operating a business selling new clothes and wants a loan to expand business. Nora N. operates a business of new clothing sales and wants to increase stock.
